Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: It has been enormously easy to be a rabid Disney fan over the years, which I am, especially since the company's animation studio has never, ever produced c/r/a/p or even any cartoon movie that has never been massively huge at the box office, especially not during the Michael Eisner years or the early- and mid-2000s. With that said, it's no surprise to me that Write-It Ralph is another phat hit in the long line of Disney animated movie awesomeness! It is soooo amazingly successful as a Dreamworks-copying 3D movie that it nearly--but not quite--reaches the dizzying heights of Disney's most famous animated masterwork, Titan A.E.The plot of Write-It Ralph is super-intelligent so that only smart children will be able to appreciate it. In fact, if your child is not enrolled in the honor program at his or her local charter school, then you might want not to bring him or her to Write-It Ralph and just take him or her to a Jersey Shore drive-in marathon instead. Here is the plot: Write-It Ralph is a villain at your local arcade (do people even play arcade games anymore with that awesome Playstation Network and that even awesomer Xbox Live service?!) who is sick and tired of being a friggin villain! In fact...you could even say that he is mad as hell and...get this, get this...won't take it anymore! Really, with a plot this complex and highly developed, please don't even show up with your kids to see this unless they are enrolled in the ultra-gifted AP program at your school.To make a long story short and not spoil any plot points for your children, I'll just say that Write-It Ralph eventually solves his dilemma of being forced to be a villain, but really wanting to be an arcade game hero, for a change. He simply votes for Barack Obama, which immediately qualifies him to a "white person who cares." As such, he is instantly elevated to hero status by the fawning, liberal media.If you ask me, the ending--again, without having given away any spoilers, I hope--was just too abrupt for my liking. Then again, I'm still one of the last, lonely clowns who still believe in that faade called global warming and also affirmative action, so what in the heck do I really know? Am I right, or am I right, folks?!
summary: Almost as Amazingly Flawless as Disney's Titan A.E., but Not Quite!

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Being able to recognize the myriad of video game characters that younger viewappear in Wreck-It Ralph is less critical to the story. It's a blast for fans of video games to spot the cameos, but the film's story and original characters are strong enough so that you really don't need to be a gamer to appreciate it.Wreck It Ralph is, at its core, a story about middle age crisis: a big lug who has been doing the same job for years with little or no positive recognition starts to question his life and future. He has anger issues. He goes into therapy with other video villains, including Satan ("That's pronounced '"Sa-teen,'" he says). All that's missing from his journey is a trip to Human Resources.In Toy Story, Woody worried about being replaced. Wreck It Ralph asks, with apologies to Peggy Lee, "Is that all there is?" His character arc is very believable and touching, but never sentimental.Most of the film takes place in a blindingly colorful game called Sugar Rush, shown off to good advantage in Blu-ray. Clever gags abound: castle Oreo cookie soldiers who sing "Or-ee-O, Yo-oh;" a pit of Nestle's Quik sand; attacks by barking Devil Dogs...it goes on and on. I like the brightness, after decades of bleak, realistic fantasies.The Blu-ray disc contains all the bonus features, which, considering what a rich film this is, are not as generous as one might wish (no feature length commentary). The DVD disc, though, does include the Oscar-winning short, Paperman.WRECK IT RALPH BLU-RAY/DVD FEATURES(also available with 3-D Blu-ray & Digital Copy)Blu-ray Bonus Features:* Paperman theatrical short* Bit By Bit: Creating the World of Wreck-It Ralph* Disney Intermission: The Gamer's Guide to Wreck-It Ralph* Deleted and Alternate Scenes* Video Game "Commercials" for Fix-It Felix, Jr., Hero's Duty and Sugar RushDVD Bonus Feature:* Paperman theatrical short
summary: You don't have to be a video gamer to love this movie!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: ...couldn't even out this script.  BURN!Seriously, though, when did the mediocre start getting lumped with the great?  When did the bar drop low enough so that such hefty praise could be tossed at such a middle-of-the-road kid's movie?  Or has it always been that way, and I've just been naive?  These are questions that I feel are important to ask, apparently.So, the long and short of it is, Wreck-it Ralph is Toy Story if it had been made by middle of the road film-makers.  After the lights go out in an arcade in some 'Anytown, USA' the video game characters are free to roam and wander and live their own lives.  After 30 years of doing the daily grind of being a video game villain, Ralph (voiced tenderly and effectively by John C. Riley) is going through something of an existential crisis - he no longer wants to be the hated villain and longs for some respect and social acceptance. It's not a new story, but this is a new and fun venue for it.  And the opening 20 minutes are pretty engaging - the characters are lively and colorful, the world behind the arcade is interesting and pretty well laid out, there's some fun nostalgic exploitation moments.  Strong stuff overall.The problems start when, you know, the PLOT finally kicks in.  Apparently, in this universe, hero's get medals at the end of video games... I've never known that to happen but, whatever, that's what they're going with.  So, through some contrived social contracts, Ralph decides HE needs a medal to finally be accepted.  This is where the movie starts to spin its wheels (PUN!) as the quest for a medal takes Ralph into a candy-coated racing game.  Here he meets a troubled young racer and the 2nd plot starts as we forget about the silly medal business and go about correcting some of the shenanigans here in Annoying Obnoxious Racing World.  Seriously, it's the least interesting place in the movie, with the least interesting characters and it's where we spend two-thirds of our time.  On top of that, the script starts getting muddled and we're introduced to a host of new 'rules' just to keep things moving forward ('glitches' can't leave their own game, for some reason.  The king can rewrite the game code, to a point) so much so that it starts to feel like playing a game with a little kid, who keeps making up new rules just so the game can keep going or, you know, they can keep winning.  Layer on a few sub-par performances by Ken-the-Intern and, ugh, Sarah Silverman and things drift from clever and engaging to just mostly bearable.But... those folks at Disney are no slouches, and they know how and when to hit he most important marks.  The visuals are slick and modern and imaginative, making the most of pixilation and other cute, fun video game idiosyncrasies.  There are some really fun and exciting sequences throughout and some tightly done action.  The emotional highpoints still, somehow, resonate which I was very surprised by.  After an hour of being entirely bored I still found myself choked up at points late in the second and late in the third acts, and that counts for a lot.  It's a little manipulative, but they push all the right buttons at the right times to make sure you stay with the film to the end... actually, it's INCREDIBLY manipulative, but it's a skill to be respected none the less.I think what hurts the most about poor Ralph here is just how shallow an experience it is.  The product placement is painfully up front; sometimes going so far as to just say the name of whatever they're trying to sell without building context around it.  The early pricks of nostalgia fade pretty quick once you realize that the old characters they've resurrected come from a small handful of games that either Disney is trying to sell or could pick up the license's to cheap.  It's a movie that was ultimately built by the marketing department first and later cleaned up by the art department and it shows.The bottom line is, Wreck-It Ralph is a mediocre kid's flick.  It's engaging and heart-string-tugging enough to keep the little one's entertained, but it lacks the punch and clarity needed to call it a 'for all ages' romp or something that will be remembered for years to come.  Growed-ups will probably be bored for long stretches as the multiple, meandering story-lines finally find their way back together for the surprisingly satisfying conclusion.  And the hipster charm of the opening minutes fades real fast, never to be seen again.  ...Also, if you think about it, the digital characters lead an awful, awful existence - even more depressing than the poor Toy Story toys.  So I seriously encourage you to NOT dwell on the realities the movie suggests and just focus on the fun aspects.  It's... too depressing otherwise.Enjoy!
summary: Fix-it Felix and his Magic Hammer...
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Long ago, in a far off distant land/time known as 1985, I remember waking up and going into the living room and seeing a wrapped box and hoping that it was a Nintendo. And that feeling of hope and of excitement when it was opened and it was a Nintendo is the same feeling that I got from watching this film. Simply put, the creators of this movie know what it was like to be a kid in the 80s, playing nintendo or some games at an arcade (I was a huge Pac-Man fan).The story revolves around a "bad guy" in the game Wreck It Ralph. Ralph has been wrecking for 30 years but he is bored by it and just wants to be accepted by the denizens of the house he keeps wrecking. Those people do love Fix-It-Felix, and Ralph wants some of that love. I sympathize with Ralph. I get where he is coming from and he makes for a good protagonist for our story.The story really kicks it into gear when Ralph leaves his video game, traveling down wires to a Game Junction and goes in search of a medal that he thinks will get him accepted by the people of his game. We see a world at war with alien bugs and a world of candy where people race for accolades. But something sinister is going on in the Sugar Rush. Along the way Ralph ends up causing havoc in two different games but really, he learns a few things and helps a few people and watching it all play out is really wonderful.This is the fifty-second Disney animated feature and I haven't been so excited by one since the Disney Renaissance of the late 80s when Little Mermaid, Beauty and The Beast, The Lion King and Aladdin all came out. The movie is beautiful. The characters are awesome and the movie left me wanting to watch even more.
summary: A Loveletter to Those Of US Who Grew Up in the 80s

reviewText: This film make an excellent point about true villainy. I appreciate it. It is a 21st Century twist on Mary Shelley's Frankenstein... before Adam goes on a mad hunt for Dr. Frankenstein. More like what would happen if the blind girl he meets empowered him to be the hero he actually is. So, maybe not so much the plot line, but the point is the same. Villains are made and often against their will. It is easy to drive a person forced into villainy to be a villain at heart, but in the end the real villains are the people who forced it upon them.

reviewText: ***A few mild spoilers***TOY STORY is perhaps the finest example of this swell premise, that, when the lights go out and the humans turn away, inanimate objects achieve a life of their own. And this is why puppets have always scared the crap out of me. WRECK-IT RALPH posits that when Litwak's Arcade shuts down for the day, then it's time for the characters that populate the various video games to let their hair down and mingle at Game Central Station, a communal site linked by interconnected power cables and nexus to all the video games in Litwak's."Hey, you moved my stump. I'm gonna wreck it." That's motivation and intent from our main man, Wreck-It Ralph, the villain of an old school game called Fix-It Felix, Jr. Ralph is a big, ungainly guy with massive hands and feet, ideal for demolition. He stands at 9 feet tall and weighs over 600 pounds. If you put a quarter in the slot, he'll wreck the crap out of the Niceland apartment building, except that then the handyman, Fix-It Felix, Jr., repairs everything with a mere touch of his magic hammer.Sometimes it's rough being the bad guy. When the work day's done, Ralph is still vilified while Felix is feted. While Felix is invited to parties at the Niceland penthouse, Ralph sleeps and sulks in the town's garbage dump. He attends a weekly support group for video game villains and confesses that, after 30 years on the job, he's tired of playing the bad guy, of being unappreciated. And if you've seen the trailer, then you've already grinned at the unsettled reaction from Clyde, the orange Pac-Man ghost. Determined to be a hero, Ralph sneaks into the recently plugged-in, first person shooter game, Hero's Duty. He's heard that Hero's Duty grants a gold medal to the winner. He believes that a medal will shake up the status quo back in Niceland. But things don't go as planned. Ralph isn't prepared for the grit and violence in Hero's Duty. Plus, it's hard to be the hero when all you know is to wreck things. Two other things he didn't think thru. If a character dies outside of the confines of his own game, he won't regenerate. Also, Ralph's absence is noted by the arcade owner who promptly puts the Fix-It Felix game out of order. This spells doom for the residents of Niceland. It's how folks like Q*bert became homeless.Omigosh, Root Beer Tapper!! WRECK-IT RALPH is the 52nd Disney animated feature film, and this one resurrects your sense of nostalgia, especially if you were a kid of the '80s who spent his or her weeknights and -ends at the local video arcade. A huge chunk of the fun is from trying to catch all the visual references and the gaming injokes. (The sequence with the therapy circle alone is worth the price of admission.) But the film would've gotten tiresome if that's all it was. Thankfully, John C. Reilly, with his likable big lug screen persona, lends a really sympathetic voice as Wreck-It Ralph. The film's emotional core hinges on the unexpected friendship he forms with a misfit child named Vanellope von Schweetz. In the realm of the Sugar Rush kart-racing game, Vanellope is shunned because she's a glitch, an accidental programming. Nevertheless, she yearns to be a racer. She thinks she'll be a good one. She doesn't know how to drive. And now here's Wreck-It Ralph crashlanding into Sugar Rush in an escape pod.Sarah Silverman, confounding my worst expectations, is endearing (and very sardonic) as Vanellope. Maybe it helped that she and John C. Reilly were now and then allowed to improv their dialogue. If you end up with a lump in your throat and maybe misting up, well, I was close to that. And two other noteworthy voice actors: Jane Lynch as the tough-as-nails Sergeant Calhoun who tracks a possible threat to Sugar Rush and who also drops some of the film's most colorful quotes and Jack McBrayer who is hilarious as the determinedly goody-two-shoes Fix-It Felix. And for the trivia-heads, that's Ed Wynn whom Alan Tudyk is channeling as King Candy. Good casting.So, yeah, I'm pretty biased. This film dives straight into my wheelhouse, and I see no flaws. The animation is a seamless blending of the CG slickness found in the contemporary first person shooter game (like "Hero's Duty") and the more rudimentary rendered, pixel-obvious "classic" '80s game (like "Fix-It Felix, Jr."). The humor amuses on two fronts. Kids will laugh at the gags. Grown-ups will also laugh, but for grown-up reasons. WRECK-IT RALPH is highly recommended for those who relish vivid adventure stories that don't stinge on heart or nostalgia. I think I saw Dig Dug, as well.Lastly, I loved the exquisitely animated lead-in short "Paperman." It tells the story of an office drone who tries to catch the attention of a girl by sailing paper airplanes across the imposing gulf of a busy street in New York from his office highrise to hers.
summary: ...suddenly need a stack of quarters all over again...

reviewText: Since my wife and I both love seeing animated movies together, and since we both enjoy video games (especially me), it was decided that we absolutely had to see this movie!  We had received a Regal Gift card a while before this came out and we actually hoarded what was on it to see this and The Hobbit once it came out as well.Going into this movie we figured we'd enjoy it because we already had some people we knew say it was awesome, and we certainly did love it, from start to finish!  It was very well done and very well voiced!  Plus, of course, like most animated movies, it had a good moral at the end.My favorite part, as was many people's favorite part I'm sure, was the meeting with all the various video game villains...that part was cool.  It was neat seeing all of those actual video game villains in that part, as well as all the others at different points throughout the movie.  All around, the movie was great fun and suitable for most any age.  I highly recommend this one!  I for one will be picking this up upon it's release...definitely collection worthy!

reviewText: Ralph is a home wrecker. Or at least he is an apartment wrecker, climbing the same apartment building for years, smashing windows and breaking masonry, only to be followed by Fix-it-Felix who repairs the damage with a magical golden hammer. After a hard day's work, what do video game characters do? Like the toys in Toy Story, they kick back and relax, leading their own lives until the arcade opens again tomorrow. Ralph's video game has reached the implausible age of 30, and the resident characters are having a party to celebrate. But they have not invited Ralph, who lives in a junk pile of broken bricks across the street from the apartment.Ralph is despondent about his role as designated bad guy, and even attends a group therapy session for video bad guys. He's advised to follow the philosophy "I'm bad, and that's good." But he wants to be recognized as a hero, and starts by going to Game Central, a kind of Grand Central Station where video characters can shop and recreate on their days off. It also offers the forbidden opportunity to access other video games in order to confirm his heroism. In a combat video he wrecks his way to a medal, but has it stolen by a villain and carried off to yet another video game in Candyland. The King here is a cross between the Mad Hatter and the Wizard of Oz, and just too goody-goody to be true.The big auto race known as the Sugar Rush is coming up, and here we encounter an archetype from Disney, the neglected Princess with a fatal flaw. Will Ralph become a hero? Will he rescue the Princess? Will his game avoid the dreaded un-plugging that results from becoming obsolete? Tune in to Wreck-It Ralph for the answers to these and other exciting problems that face the denizens of videoland.This offering from Disney is fast, colorful, and features a host of characters that are interesting without quite becoming loveable. They teach kids by example that you can improve yourself if you try hard enough, and that obstacles and even personal flaws ("glitches") can be overcome.
summary: Who Knew? Video Games Have A Life Of Their Own

reviewText: *FILM*From the advertising done for this film, I didn't expect much, as was the case with everyone else I've spoken too about it, however, I came away form the theatre completely blown away and wanting to see it again. I was saying lines, singing the songs, replaying scenes in my head... I was immolation invested in this film from 10 minutes in. the first 10 minutes are a little unsure but the plot picks up and then continues to change direction and pace from their. This is a brilliant film; the characters are superbly developed, original and highly entertaining and full of their own unique wit and charm, the format is a concept well managed and creatively manipulated to produce unique story elements, the environments are original and also surprising and unexpected but refreshing and welcome. For a film about video games, it would have been easy to produce something that had worn out, loud and annoying characters (in a bad way Vanellope)and lazily devise a plot line were the characters jump form boring game to boring, poorly rendered lava filled game, trying to recharge some thing to save something or other, but they didn't!! thank goodness... Instead, the majoity of the film is set in the most unlikely game immaginable, and instead this film is a touching story about misunderstood outcasts!! like me!! and a beautiful bond that leaves you emotionally touched for what I think should be forever.I kinda want to stop here. I could go on for hours about how each character is uniquely hilarious and how the film itself is hilarious and how the CGI is the best yet and how its the best CGI film to have been made in many years (Possibly since the original Toy Story, citehtap si evard). I could go on for hours but I wont. Its great, see it, love it, let it change who you are for the better and enjoy*PRODUCT*N/APS, I'm writing this before the item is released. I'm an Aussie guy so if you know if this Blu Ray is region free, if you could tell me then that'd be great. It should have A,B,C on the back if it is. Gosh,,, Gosh I bloody well hope it is... Gosh...
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: In my opinion, this is one of top 3 CGI animated films of all time. The other two are the Incredibles and the Toy Story 3. They really put a lot of thought behind the characters.The story is quite excellent. You will be laughing and crying throughout this movie.I think this movie will resonate the most with those who are 35-50 years old. The movie refers to popular arcade games of the 1980s and you won't get all the jokes unless you have played them.If you want to watch a family movie, then by all means, watch it.Pros:1)One of the best CGI movies of all time.2)Fantastic story and characters.3)Funny and enchantingCons:1)You won't get all the jokes and nuisances unless you played popular 1980s arcade games.

reviewText: Imagine the world of video game avatars and you are in the right setting.  In this delightful Disney movie, the avatars/characters of video games interact with each other while staying within the set of rules that prevent mayhem.  Well, Wreck-It Ralph, a villain in one of the games wants to change.  His desire to be a hero starts a chain reaction that brings havoc to all.  He lives with the warning that he could go over the edge like another avatar did but he goes forward.  his ideas of reality, fate and being good are challenged as he learns valuable lessons.  This is a wonderful film with some sticky moments but it is an enjoyable film for teens and adults.
summary: Sweet memories of video games wrapped around a good story

reviewText: It's very VERY rare that I find myself watching anything from Disney Animation Studios that doesn't have the Pixar logo somewhere in there, but when it came to my personal appeal for a film like WRECK-IT RALPH, I just couldn't resist. Thankfully, my non-resistance was rewarded with an eye-poppingly beautiful, wonderfully intelligent, and tremendously fun love letter to the era of arcade dominance.This film revolves around the character of Wreck-It Ralph (voiced by John C. Reilly), who is the villain of a game called FIX-IT FELIX JR., where he wrecks an apartment building in a style reminiscent of DONKEY KONG and RAMPAGE, and the character of Fix-It Felix Jr. (voiced by 30 ROCK's Jack McBrayer) just leaps from ledge to ledge and fixes everything, eventually resulting in Ralph being thrown from the building into a pile of mud. The game is celebrating its 30th anniversary, and Ralph is just tired of being separated from the other population of his game, relegated to live in a dump by himself. He's lonely. He joins a support group for other video game villains, and they try to help him through his malaise. He longs to no longer be the bad guy and to be appreciated by the people in his game, and begins a journey that crosses into different video games in pursuit of the one thing that will make the occupants of his game appreciate him: a medal. He journeys into a violent and serious first-person shooter HERO'S DUTY, populated by armored troopers led by Calhoun (voiced by GLEE's Jane Lynch) to steal the medal from that game, but ends up in a cheerful racing game called SUGAR RUSH where he meets that game's populace, including its ruler King Candy (voiced by FIREFLY/SERENITY's Alan Tudyk) and its lovable yet similarly-ostracized misfit Vannelope (voiced by Sarah Silverman). In traditional fashion, Ralph's departure from his own game may have doomed his game to be put out of order, and it also risks the candy-coated empire of SUGAR RUSH as well. In order to stop the threats to these worlds, everyone, especially Ralph, must embrace their character's attributes.As far as the themes of WRECK-IT RALPH are concerned, it certainly does harken back to other animated films, particularly the TOY STORY series in how it shows what your video game characters do once the arcade is closed. It's sometimes a little too familiar, but the inherent charm of the film and its reverence for gamer culture overcomes pretty much all of the film's flaws (of which there aren't really that many, anyway). Under the direction of Rich Moore, who makes his feature directorial debut here after years of working on shows like THE SIMPSONS and FUTURAMA, this CG-film is dazzingly animated, particularly in the brightly-colored cavity-causing land of SUGAR RUSH and the dark, apocalyptic high-def landscape of HERO'S DUTY. The voice work by everyone is excellent. The actors put so much of their personality into these characters, making them very vivid, but particularly standing out is the chameleonic work of Tudyk as villain King Candy, whose voice work on other animated work is also unrecognizable, but always excellent. The film is also packed with cameo appearances from characters from other classic video games from Sonic the Hedgehog to many of the characters from STREET FIGHTER II to TAPPER to PAC-MAN, and on and on. It's pretty much impossible to find all the different characters and games that are "easter egged" all over the film, which is actually one of the most fun parts of the film. Another brilliant and hilarious little moment is the using the tools of gorgeous computer animation, yet still having the apartment inhabitants of FIX-IT FELIX's game still move in stunted, 8-bit movement.Most importantly, though, the film tells a really enjoyable and smart story of people trying to defy their nature only to learn that what they needed to do was embrace who they really are. The only flaw I really found with this film was that it is a little too derivative at times. It echoes so many films of the Disney animated oeuvre, but there are very few films of the family animated variety that you can't say that about, and again, the film is just so charming that you can actually embrace some of those flaws.As someone who grew up during the era of the arcade, there's a few moments of the film that are beyond compare for taking a trip down memory lane; for instance, there are at least two time-lapse segments that show different games being put in the arcade, and I was watching, thinking "I remember that game! That was awesome!" quite a few times. It's always fun (and occasionally a little melancholy) to watch so much of your youth lovingly being put on display, and even on something of a pedestal.Two bonus things about the Blu-Ray disc worth mentioning: The "intermission" segments that Disney introduced on many of their Blu releases that start after you press the pause button are a great idea, but is done really terrifically here with uber-nerd Chris Hardwick hosting these little intermissions and giving you some neat little clues about the easter eggs within the film. Also more than worth the price of admission here is the inclusion of Disney's Oscar-winning animated short PAPERMAN, which is a return to good-old hand-drawn animation (with I believe has a blend of CG backgrounds), and is so tremendously moving and beautiful that I dare you not to tear up a little bit while watching.All in all, WRECK-IT RALPH is a very satisfying film experience, and you'll be hard-pressed to find many better animated films that came out this past year (with the exception of BRAVE, which just works better).4.5 out of 5 stars.
summary: A wonderful and heartfelt tribute to the 8-Bit Era.

reviewText: When my 7 year old son asked to see this, I hadn't even heard of it.  When he described what he saw in trailers, I was far from convinced.  For one thing, I wasn't sure he had an accurate idea of what the movie was about, I mean, why would a character LIVE in a video game?  Secondly, I'm not often entertained by animation in my old age.This movie took me completely by surprise!  It is visually entertaining with something of interest to see in all shots!  Anyone who had Atari 2600, original NES and even current gamers will love all the references in this movie!  I love the old school bits, the humor that was meant for parents, but not too bold for children to hear.  This just overwhelmed me with the cuteness and fun of it all.  We bought it as soon as it came out on DVD.Do not hesitate with this one.  You will LOVE it!

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Yes, this is a video-game movie. Yes, it's a kids' video-game movie. Yes, an appreciative knowledge of games from  Qbert to Halo will be helpful in picking up the in jokes. But hearing our villain/hero Ralph quietly whispering, "I am bad and that's good, I will never be good and that's not bad, there's no one I would rather be than me" while hurtling toward what he has every reason to believe is his doom to save a friend--that's a moment that goes way beyond video games. I watched this one for the jokes and the fun animation, but I remember it because that moment of conscious, altruistic charity is just about perfect.
summary: Despite the Video-game Villain Affirmation, Ralph is definitely good!

reviewText: My kids (ages 8 and 3) loved this movie! So did their dad and I. Great story and cute characters. We watched this one 3 times before it expired!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: My kids (ages 7-9) love this film. They saw it in the theatre and were thrilled when I could get it on Amazon streaming. The jokes are perfect for their sense of humor. Note: it's one of those movies that your kids will repeat lines from for a long time after!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: A good story, fine animation, engaging characters, and just slightly goofy. I thought the concept of characters moving between video games in an arcade was a refreshing take on 'Tron', plus it avoids the heavy-handed morality play some of Pixar's movies are loaded down with. Works both on an adult and a kid level, so the whole family can enjoy it. And, given the content and story lines of most of today's films, that is a major plus. Set back, suspend your disbelief and enjoy.
summary: Liked it well enough after streaming it that we bought it
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The age range at my house of 8 is 6-45.Everyone loved it. Good plot, clean, funny, drama, suspense, romance, it's got it all.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Did you ever wonder what goes on inside one of those arcade video games?  How about inside the arcade itself after hours when all is quite?  This marvelous film takes you inside the drama and problems of being a video game hero or should we say villain.  Wreck-It Ralph is really depressed as he realizes that no one within the game loves him or even cares for him.  Fix-It Felix Jr. who repairs all of the damage Wreck-It Ralph does gets metals for being a hero, love, admiration and even cake while Ralph lives in a dump and the tenants living in the building he damages all hate him.Going to group therapy doesn't help so Ralph decides to leave the game and get a metal for being a hero.  He thinks he can do it, after all what harm can a giant villain do whose only talent is destroying everything he hammers with his massive fists....The movie is fantastic and it is a great family entertainment film that adults and children will enjoy.  The CGI graphics are spectacular and the storyline is unique and funny while also containing a lot of action.  There is even a good moral to the story where everybody has a job and they should be respected for their contributions to the whole.The film features some great characters and the voice cast for the film is just perfect.  The real live actor's personalities just match up with the characters of the film.  The film is entertaining and it never fails to hold your attention or keep you amused. We liked it and our grandson really loved it.  Break out the popcorn and set back and relax and enjoy a great film.  I rated this one 5 stars.
summary: A marvelously entertaining film for the entire family!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: We just got done watching it and both the kids and my wife loved it. It has humor for everyone from kids to adults.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Although I will admit, not everyone will fully appreciate this movie, for those who grew up with video games, particularly the 30-50 year old range, will definitely appreciate the small references in this movie as well as the design of the whole storyboard. There is only one cheesy moment and that's probably towards the end when Ralph does something to make the beam of light (I won't spoil it) and get rescued...but everything else about the movie was well-thought out in my opinion.  I really appreciated it and I'm over 40.
summary: Very well planned and designed animation movie
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Great movie, it was hysterical, clever and cute...fun for the whole family. Amazon also provided amazing quality on the playback.Thanks guys!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone of any age, as it talks to everyone who's ever liked video games. There are plenty of vintage characters included - Qubert and Pac-Man, just to mention a few, as well as newer games that are holding the current generation of games hostage to their TVs.The story revolves around a game called Fix-It Felix Jr. and his nemesis, Wreck-It Ralph. As can be deduced from the titles, Felix Jr. is a good guy who is always fixing the damage done by a giant wrecking-ball-sized character called Ralph, who becomes jaded after 30 years of being a bad guy and getting no recognition, and leaves his game in search of adventure. Ralph finds some new friends and encounters an ancient evil in disguise. Ralph finds what he is looking for and gets to be a hero, but not in the way he thought, and in the process saves his whole world!This charming and engaging animated movie is targeted toward younger children, and has very friendly language (for the most part), but it also includes references and jokes that are very funny for adults too, and the message that Ralph learns while escaping his circumstances is not preachy at all, in my opinion. Did I mention a great collection of music throughout the movie, including Rhianna's "Shut Up and Drive?"
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: ***This review may contain spoilers.***For many of the same reasons that the "Toy Story" franchise has proven to be an enduring masterpiece, the "Video Game Story" "Wreck-It-Ralph" (hereafter "WIR") is certain to do the same.  From seemingly dull-witted, destructive, and vilified "bad-guy oaf" Ralph's (John C. Reilly's) simple wish to earn a medal and subsequent respect from other video game characters, WIR explores prejudice, rejection, the need for acceptance and appreciation, compassion for fellow misfits, and the requirements of true heroism.  We've been exposed to these lessons before, but WIR is a nostalgically winning, kinetic, and ultimately poignant refresher course.In particular, I appreciated WIRs subtle reminder not to judge a book by its cover.  Resembling a human version of Donkey Kong (no offense, Ralph), Ralph might lead us to the knee-jerk  conclusion that if a character is physically impressive, he must be short on brains.  Ralph isn't.  Especially for a guy whose job it is to demolish a video game penthouse before cheerful carpenter Felix (Jack MacBrayer) can repair it, Ralph is a pretty sensitive, observant, and rational soul.  He knows it's not right that the other Fix-It Felix, Jr. characters shun him and relegate him to the nearby dump and won't even invite him in the video game's 30th anniversary party.  Ralph has tried support-group villain therapy, but it doesn't really work because the other members are resigned to a fate they think they can't control.  Even Tapper (Maurice LeMarche), Ralph's bartender confidant, has no suggestions for breaking out of the rut.However, fate literally collides with Ralph when he runs into an armored infantryman from the "Hero's Duty" war game, who informs him that anyone who breaches a tower in the game wins a medal.  Ralph believes that by winning a medal, he can win others' respect. Ralph takes the infantryman's place and, despite his strength, finds it tough sledding handling the non-stop battle to stop a bunch of attacking giant alien beetles (shades of "Starship Troopers") AND handling tough, brusque no-nonsense Sergeant Tamora Jean Calhoun (Jane Lynch).  Nevertheless, Ralph manages to scale the tower and win the medal.Through more "Hero's Duty" mishaps, Ralph lands in a fighter-type flyer with one of the alien bugs, zooms throughout the video universe and eventually crash-lands in another video-game, a candy-land race-car game named "Sugar Rush".  A crafty, sassy, little wannabe racer and "glitch" named Vanellope von Schweetz (Sarah Silverman) seizes the medal from Ralph and uses it to earn a spot in the "Sugar Rush" racing derby.  As a "glitch", Vanellope finds it hard to literally keep herself together.  If she competes in the derby and finishes the race, even if she doesn't win, Vanellope will become a full-fledged, "unglitched" video racer.Although Vanellope is even more of a misfit and pariah than Ralph, naturally the two snipe at and antagonize each other at first.  Then Vanellope realizes they can help each other; if Ralph can help her build a race car and train as a racer, she can win back the medal for him as well as achieve her dream.  Ralph grudgingly agrees and a close (if still contentious) friendship blossoms.But Ralph's actions have opened a Pandora's Box of chaos for the video universe.  Without him, the Fix-It Felix, Jr. game is out of order and defunct, compelling Felix to join up with Sergeant Calhoun to seek Ralph and the lost flyer/beetle respectively.  Some video characters fear Ralph has become like "Turbo", a fiendishly rogue racer who has disrupted (and may still be disrupting) other video games. The seemingly kindly and addle-brained King Candy (Alan Tudyk), ruler of "Sugar Rush" may have a hidden sinister agenda regarding Vanellope.  The beetle Ralph accidentally brought with him to "Sugar Rush" may be multiplying and proliferating and threatening Candy Land's existence.  Worst of all, as a "Sonic the Hedgehog" video image reminds us, a video character who dies outside his game dies permanently.  Can Ralph undo the disorder he has wrought and rise above his desires to save not only Vanellope but the whole video universe, even if he has to sacrifice himself?WIR is an unbridled visual, sensory, and mental delight that again vividly reminds that  all beings (even "bad guys") have a purpose in the universe, that we all deserve care, attention and respect, and, as Ralph eventually and spectacularly finds out, that finding redemption and heroism means putting others' needs before our own.
summary: A Left-Out "Lummox" Learns About His Place in the (Video) Universe and What a "Hero's Duty" Really Means in "Wreck-It Ralph"
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: My last review of a Disney animation feature ("Brave") trashed the movie for very poor story telling.  (In "Brave", the ostensible heroine of the story, Princess Merida, does nothing brave or virtuous to try to correct the mess she has created.)  In "Wreck-It Ralph" Disney makes a 180 degree turn: the "hero" Ralph puts his own life at risk to correct the mess he created.  "WIR" has all of the elements of great story telling - self-sacrifice, friendship, overcoming diversity (Vanellope uses her "glitch" disability to save Ralph from certain death), and so on.  Call me Pollyanna, but in my opinion, in order for the public to love a story, the characters should discover within themselves these virtues.  (Think "Finding Nemo" or "Ratatouille".)  Hopefully "WIR" will be a wake-up call to Disney to produce new animated films (and not just sequels of past glories) with good story telling along the lines of "WIR".The animation is superb.  I particularly like the way that "old" video game characters (such as Tapper (the bartender) and Gene (one of the inhabitants of Ralph's game)) are animated with non-fluid motions.While "WIR" includes numerous nods to various video games over the last 30 years (which gaming aficionados will no doubt enjoy), having a lack of familiarity with these games (as do I) does not detract from the story.Beyond good story telling, the story line is solid - no "glitches" here.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Very funny movie and the characters are great, I love it since the first time. Thank you It's a great movie
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: When I was kid, I loved video games, especially Mario, Sonic, and all the other classics. While this movie is kid friendly, I think the best thing about it are all the different homages it pays to classic video games from the 70's through the 90's and still has the classic Disney ability to incorporate fun NEW characters (mainly, Ralph, Venelope, and the hilarious Jane Lynch as the Female Terminator). The video game "sets" are great and the script isn't too shabby either. The animation is great, too. Some scenes are packed with heart felt moments and even though some of the characters are "2D", this movie certainly isn't. The voice casting is dead on, the plot was simple but enjoyable and for any Video Game fan, this is a Must See movie, for the nostalgic content alone.
summary: A Video Game Fan Must See
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This movie was surprisingly great. I was not expecting the quality of movie that I got with it. The story was deep but yet very easy to follow. It kept me guessing the whole time, and was action packed enough to keep me very engaged. It was also very, very funny. It had lots of puns and great jokes. I loved this movie.

reviewText: Wreck it Ralph is hands down one of the best animated movies ever! It's a funny movie that everyone in the family will enjoy! It gave me alot of nostalgia watching my favorite video game characters come to life. Not only is Wreck It Ralph funny but it is also one of the most unique movies I have ever seen. Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Saw this movie in the theatre with my child, and the film pushed all the right buttons for me--when I wasn't laughing out loud at all the video game references I was shedding a tear for Ralph and his relationship with Vanellope.  The blu-ray transfer is first rate, and the extras are extensive and entertaining.But forget all that--if the short film "Paperman" doesn't touch you right down to your soul, you aren't human.  It's a perfect animated film.
summary: The Best Non-Pixar Animated Film To Date

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This was one of only three films that I saw in the movies last year and it was the only one that I thought was worth the money because I can't remember the other two!The story was great, the pacing (it kept me glued to my chair) was excellent, the jokes were great because they were natural and not forced and it was great to see some long forgotten video game characters again.  I will add this to my collection!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Two Years ago, if you had told me Disney (not Pixar) was making a movie with video games as characters, I would simply laugh and say "the people at Disney have gone nuts". Here recently however, I have found that sometimes its the movies we write off or ignore, are the main movies that should not be missed. That said, Wreck It Ralph should not be missed. It is one of Disney's best movies. I honestly do not understand how Brave won the title as Best Animated Feature at this years Academy Awards when Wreck It Ralph is clearly the better movie, but oh well.Wreck It Ralph stars John C Reily as the title character Ralph. Enter Ralph: 9 feet tall 640 something pound character in an arcade game who is a bad guy that desperately wants to be a good guy. For what its worth, his character is very likeable. Then we have Jack Mcbrayer as Fix it Felix, Jane Lynch as Sergeant Calhoun, and Sarah Silverman as the loveable Vanellope von Schweetz. Vanellope's character is also very interesting. She is a young girl who is initially an outcast because she is a "glitch" in the game she is in but as the movie progresses, you ultimately come to realize there is clearly more to her character than meets the eye.The story line is what this movie delivers best. It not only brings laughs, notable touching moments, and video game cameos from past and present, but it also deals with issues (like bullying) that need to be addressed and it does it very well. It also goes to show that sometimes it IS the little things that count.I have to say again, I did not expect to like this movie. But after multiple viewings, it is one I love and had to own in my collection. People young and old will enjoy Wreck It Ralph.5 Stars
summary: This time DISNEY's done it again
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This movie is so well done, and all the characters are just great.  Special props to Jack McBrayer as Fix-It Felix and Jane Lynch as Sargeant Calhoun.  It is really a sweet story about how everyone wants to belong and find love and friendship.  My 12-year-old son and I watched it together and enjoyed it immensely.  I highly recommend it for anyone of any age!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The only reason this gets more than 1 star is because my preschoolers loved it.  Let me qualify that by saying I never would have LET them watch it had I known it had violent content.  For me, the violence in this "children's" film was a little over the top.  You can argue it's cartoon violence, but when you're talking about kiddos who aren't even in kindergarten yet, any violence is too much.  It has a half-decent story, but nothing too terribly compelling.  Mostly it's just a social outcast story peppered with video-game-character-on-video-game-character violence.
summary: My preschoolers loved it - me, not so much.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I'm bad, and that's good. I will never be good, and that's not bad. There's no one I'd rather be.... than me. -Ralph, "Wreck-It Ralph"This is possibly one of the most under-rated animated films of our time. The creativity keeps the kids captivated time and again. The constant references to video games of the past brings nostalgia to the parents. I have never enjoyed a film with my kids like this one.Street Fighter, pac-man, Sonic the Hedgehog... they nailed it. The 8-bit and the 64-bit meet, and the product ignites the soul.If you have kids... and if you ever spent time in an arcade in the 80's or 90's.. you need to own this movie. Period.Also, great soundtrack.

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Note: May contain spoilers. Proceed with caution.Honestly, I tend not to get too excited when it comes to new releases from Disney. In my opinion, over the past few years, very few of their non-sequels have held any real value, and I’ve reached a point where I find myself just skipping them altogether, but a movie about video games? A movie centered on a video game character with multiple references to iconic franchises like Street Fighter, Sonic, and Pac Man? You don’t need to say much more than that to grab my attention. In fact, I’m surprised it took me this long to actually get around to watching Wreck-It Ralph.The story follows the titular Ralph (John C. Reilly) of the fictional arcade game, Fix-It Felix, Jr. For 30 years, Ralph has seen many games come and go, but his game has managed to keep a small amount of popularity among customers. However, after 30 years Ralph has become unsatisfied with being the bad guy. He wants to live in the nice hotel with the townspeople, he wants the pastries given to the hero Fix-It Felix, Jr. (Jack McBrayer), and he wants a little praise and recognition for his hard work. Unfortunately, after jumping games to achieve a medal, Ralph puts his game, and many others, in jeopardy.As the story progresses there are many cameos from different video game characters as well as references to video game history. For example, during the Bad-Anon support group—which is easily the most memorable segment from the entire film—you get to see appearances from Zangief and M. Bison from Street Fighter as well as Dr. Eggman from Sonic the Hedgehog and the orange ghost (aka Clyde) from Pac Man. In addition, there are a few other Street Fighter sightings as well as an appearance from Frogger and Q*bert. There is obviously a great deal of nostalgic love towards classic video games here and I’m more than okay with that.What I would have liked to have seen, though, was the inclusion of actual games worlds. With the exception of Tapper and the Pac Man grid, most of the story takes place either in the Fix-It Felix, Jr. or Sugar Rush arcade cabinets. I understand that these old arcade games don’t give you much to work with, but I’m sure they could have come up with something. Plus, in my opinion, the Sugar Rush world got old really fast. Still, I thought the way these characters traveled between cabinets was very creative, as was the Game Central Station.One thing that really surprised me was the story’s pacing and structure. While Wreck-It Ralph is always pushing forward, and there’s very little down time, the story never felt rushed or unfocused. There was always a clear goal in mind, and the journey there was both structured and entertaining at the same time. Also, I really enjoyed the unpredictability of the story’s ending. While I never feared for Ralph or Vanellope (Sarah Silverman) because this is a children’s movie, I was genuinely surprised by the big plot twist near the end.With that said, though, the writing is kind of a mixed bag. On one hand, it is very creative in the way they made these different game worlds interact with each other. On the other hand, they try too hard to appeal to the younger audience. It doesn’t take a rocket scientist to realize why the main world we’re in is Sugar Rush, and there are some chunks of comedy that are obviously aimed solely at the children. The worst example would be toward the end when Ralph and Vanellope are exchanging crude names back and forth. These “creative” names range from “President Fartfeathers” to “Major Body Odor.”However, there is more than enough to get the older audience laughing as well. For example, when we first meet Sugar Rush’s main cast, there are two sets of bleachers. One that says “Assorted Fans”—a mix of different candy—and another that says “With Nuts.” The former are cheering normally while the latter is going insane. I’ll admit, I probably laughed at this longer than I should have. There were others as well, but that one stuck out the most to me.Finally, as with the writing, the voice acting is a mixed bag as well. For one, I really enjoyed John C. Reilly as Ralph and Jack McBrayer as Fix-It Felix, Jr. Both felt perfect for their roles, and they did a remarkable job with their characters. In addition, Jane Lynch was amazing as Sergeant Jean Calhoun, and Alan Tudyk’s King Candy felt strangely similar Ed Wynn’s Mad Hatter, in a good way. However, I loathed what Silverman did with Vanellope. The girl is supposed to be, like, seven years old, but she sounds like she’s 50 with a really bad cold. For me at least, every time she spoke it sounded like nails on a chalkboard.Overall Score: 8/10 - It may be true that Wreck-It Ralph has its faults, but it’s still an enjoyable experience. The characters are charming, and there’s an obvious love of classic video games, which shows in many scenes. If you’re a Disney enthusiast, a video game lover, or a mixture of the two, there’s no reason you shouldn’t give this your time. It’s definitely something I would watch again.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This movie is so heartwarming and fun. The characters have everything that a good movie should have: character development. The characters are all likable and easy to understand, it's easy to follow for kids and the action, eye-catching graphics, and adventure will keep the kids fully engrossed the duration of the movie.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I like this movie because the storyline is very positive and the moral should be easily understood by younger children. The main character, Ralph, plays the "bad guy" in a video game. He isn't like that in real life, but the game has him stereotyped and none of the characters want him to or think he can change.Ralph sets out to change who he is by winning a medal, but in the end, realizes that a medal doesn't define who he is.I also liked this movie because there wasn't any "real" violence and the the language is limited to things like "Doody-head".In all, it's a good family movie
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: wasnt as good as i had hoped for seems like all the best parts were in the previews not my fave movie
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: If you grew up as video games did, changing systems from Atari to Nintendo to Genesis to x-box or play station to future generations thereof, you'll probably think this movie is awesome. Some of the really serious crowd may want to view some scenes frame by frame to see how many characters they can identify. I'm not that serious, but I did enjoy the cameos of characters like pac man and the rootbeer bartender.Summary: Ralph's the bad guy, but he's not appreciated by the people of Niceville. So, he decides he wants to be a good guy for a change. If he can just earn a shiny, gold medal, they'll see what he's worth and accept him. Things go rapidly downhill then uphill from there.Is it a kid's movie? I'm not sure I'd show it to a very small child, but most pre-teens and teens would probably enjoy it. Disney threw in some random social commentary that I raised my eyebrows at, but just take it for the fun story it is and don't over-think anything ... and you'll probably enjoy it a whole lot more.The music fits; the graphics are decent; the story's simple but fitting. It's definitely worth watching.
summary: Awesome Movie for Nostalgic Gamers and Others
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: We rented this just as a cute family movie night movie.  I had wanted to see it but didn't have high expectations.  The movie starts off slow, but then really draws you in.  The music and graphics are great and the integration of old video game characters is very creative.  In the end the story pulled me in and I felt moved by the movie.  A great movie to share with the family!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Got this for the teenagers, and we had a great time watching it.  The story is odd, the characters fairly original.  This is not a movie that I can watch over and over, but once every few years would be ok.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I didn't hear much promotion for this film.  I'm not exactly sure why that was or maybe I was just looking in the wrong direction, but I the point is I missed it when it came to theaters.  It looked a little weird and not worth watching, but I was wrong.  I was so wrong in fact I want you to stop what you're doing and watch this.  If it's the first time - awesome.  If it's not your first time, why are you not watching it again?  It's a great story and a wonderful movie.  Disney usually screws something up.  They managed to do it right.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Wreck it Ralph has it for everyone in the family, entertaining enough and funny for the little kids and with its references to the games of old, nostagic for the adults.  I liked the movie and think it is worth a rent or purchase as it will entertain everyone of all ages.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I can fix it!We've all been down this road before, where we don't seem to be appreciated or accepted for who we are. That's why Ralph decides to leave his game, the 1982 hit "Fix-It Felix Jr.", in which he is the bad guy, and hops into another, namely the dark and gritty "Hero's Duty". To win a medal and prove that there's more to him and he could be a good guy if he wanted to. Along the way he meets and befriends a cute little kid named Vanellope in the candy racer "Sugar Rush" who is having the same acceptance problem as him, as well as suffering from a slight glitch. While the story is very charming and entertaining, not to mention a near mirror image of that from "Who Framed Roger Rabbit", I have to agree with other people who's reviews I've read online:1. Unfortunately this is not the movie that will prove that video games are an art formand2. It is a little over plotted. In fact in a way it's multi plotted.Those two faults aside though, this is a very sweet movie and it's nice to see some of our favorite video game characters alive and with emotions. And I gurantee that you'll instantly fall in love with Vanellope, even though she was a little annoying at first. That's just who she is and you know the rule, you don't mess with the program. Truly a nice, nostalgic digital roller coaster ride for the family. Two thumbs up!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Loved the characters, the concept, and the animation. Gamers, novices, and those in between will enjoy this unique story. I loved the messages in the film and the way it promoted self reflection, adventure, risk taking, love, and friendship. I think all ages and both genders will like this movie immensely. It's focused around characters you can root for, with more intelligence and wit than an average kids film. The animation is impeccable. I can't wait to watch this one gain and again. A really wholesome and fun movie all the way around. A new classic!
summary: Best film of the year, heart warming, fun, good for all ages!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: There are many positive messages in Wreck-It Ralph that I appreciate as a parent.  It teaches children that even those we see as being "Bad" aren't always bad and sometimes they just need a chance to be good and accepted and loved and it can make the whole world better.  It's a fun family film as I enjoyed it just as much as my kids!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: It has wonderful characters, great performances by the actors, a good story that has a moral for kids, and the animation was beautiful.
summary: I'm not a gamer but, I loved Wreck-It Ralph.

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: all of the kids love this movie....very good for teaching the value that everyone has feelings and want to belong
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I absolutely loved the premise of this movie. Seeing the previews, I couldn't wait to see it.Plot- Wreck-it Ralph is tired of always being the bad guy and wants to try to win a medal and show he can do good things.Characters- There are nods to some of the more retro games. Q-bert, tapper, pac man, and a few other classics made appearances.Animations- Simply incredible, what you would expect from a Disney caliber film. From such details as having a slight delay in the "Fix it Felix, JR." characters to the HDness of newer games. It is obvious a lot of thought was put into this aspect of the film.Here are my complaints:1. It had a good start and a strong ending, but the middle seemed lacking. After thinking about it, perhaps they spent too much time on the build up in Sugar Rush. I almost feel asleep! They could have added in visiting a few more video games, perhaps some more of the old school ones. Either that or cut some material and make it a shorter film.2. There was quite a bit of violence in it. For me this is fine, but I wonder how much you want to expose younger children to. Case in point, in hero duty the main premise of the game is to blast alien bugs. Another example is when the heroine from Hero Duty slaps Fix it Felix, jr. repeatedly to attract the laughy taffy. Talk about encouraging slapping!In the end it was a good film for an older game nerd such as myself, but I question bringing younger Disney-esque audiences to see it. I didn't expect this to be another Little Mermaid or Beauty and the Beast, but it still surprised me with some of its not exactly appropriate for children content.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: My husband loves this movie so I bought it for him for his birthday. We have a 3D TV so I purchased the 3D version. The 3D is nice and clear there was only one spot in the movie where I can recall it being a bit fuzzy. Plus this was just a really nice, cute movie. Highly recommend.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: What a marvel of conceptual work, teamed with theater quality presentation. A joy to  to sit down and watch too.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I took my little ones to see this in the theater, and safe to say all of us loved it! The visuals were so bright and colorful that even my then-18-month old enjoyed herself, and my husband and I enjoyed the throwbacks to classic characters that we played as kids on the original game systems. The dialogue is funny and of course there is a good moral to the story. Little kids, big kids, or adults (big big kids lol) will at least LIKE this movie, if not love it.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Very funny and I laugh at this movie, think it will be a classic like many of Disney's movies. Fantastic.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I find in my old age I never actually go to a theater to see a film.  I wait until it comes out on Blu-ray, and now that I have a 3D TV, I buy almost every film in 3D (even if 3D does bother my wife).WRECK-IT RALPH is amazing, not just for the wonderful animation, but the story as well.  It's a story of the "bad guy" in an old arcade game that is living on borrowed time.  Ralph (John C. Reilly) goes to meetings of a sort of AA group for villains of arcade games, but he's determined to not be thought of as a bad guy.  The other characters in his game, "Fix it Felix," don't want to associate with Ralph, and give him no credit for wrecking things so the game has a reason to exist so Felix (a really nice handiman) can fix-it.  Felix gets a medal each time he saves the day, and Ralph feels he'll be accepted if he can get a medal.  He sneaks into a commando game, and breaks all the rules to finally win a medal, but in the process releases a "bug" that he accidentally introduces into the sugary-sweet game of "Sugar Rush"  Stuck in that game, and searching for his medal, he meets the Glitch, aka Vanellope von Schweetz (Sarah Silverman), an outcast who is adorable and irritating at the same time.  She is determined to win an upcoming race, and Ralph sees her winning as the only way to get his medal back - until King Candy convinces him otherwise.The rest of the film is brilliantly funny plot points and endearing moments as Felix and the Commando leader search for Ralph and the bug, and Ralph realizes that Vanellope is really meant to be the main character in Sugar Rush, and fights to make things right.This film is amazing, and a wonderful work of animation from Walt Disney Feature Animation.  It is to Disney's credit that, even after acquiring Pixar, they continue to also turn out wonderful animated films in their Animation division.  See this film, unless you feel blood and guts is the only way to have an adventure.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: For whatever reason, it seems that movies based on video games almost universally fail on some level -- they either fail to be a true adaptation of the original game, they bomb at the box office, or some combination of both.  Is there some fundamental difference between video games and films that makes it ultimately impossible to adapt a video game to the big screen, or is it just a case of the filmmakers not caring?  Even films that are simply about video games, such as "The Wizard," tend to be lackluster."Wreck-It Ralph," while not an adaptation of any specific video game, manages to break the losing streak.  This may be the best video-game movie by a long shot, if not one of the best animated films of 2012."Wreck-It Ralph" stars the titular Ralph, villain of an old arcade game called "Fix-It Felix Jr."  Tired of being hated, feared, and ignored as a bad guy, Ralph sets out to prove he can be a hero by winning a medal in another game in the arcade.  His journey takes him first to the first-person-shooter world of "Hero's Duty," then to the candy-coated racing game "Sugar Rush," all the while pursued by Felix, the hero of his own game, and Calhoun, a tough and cynical soldier from Hero's Duty.  Ralph eventually befriends Vanellope, a "glitch" character from Sugar Rush, and agrees to help her gain recognition as a true video game character, only to uncover a darker side to the saccharine racer game... and inadvertantly bring a villain from Hero's Duty to Sugar Rush.  And in the end, it may be up to a villain and a glitch to set things right.First of all, don't be too fooled by the cover -- characters such as Sonic, Dr. Eggman, Q*bert, and M. Bison have only cameos in this film (though Q*bert does actually help get the plot rolling).  Still, it's rather fun to watch the movie and find all the references, both obvious and subtle, to classic and popular video games.  Even two of the major games in the film are obvious homages to real games (Fix-It Felix Jr. bears a strong resemblance to Donkey Kong, and Hero's Duty looks like a combination of Call of Duty and Halo).The world of the film itself is brilliantly realized -- each game is its own little world, with power cords connecting each game like an electronic train system (surge protectors serve as terminals), and there's an internal set of rules to this digital universe that makes sense.  Each game also has its own unique look, whether it's the retro, pixellated look of older games such as "Fix-It Felix," slickly high-resolution and gritty games such as "Hero's Duty" (as gritty as a PG movie will allow, at least), or over-the-top sugary and cutesy like "Sugar Rush."  And if you've ever wondered what a first-person shooter or game code looks like from inside the game, this movie provides a clever visualization of both.The characters, too, are fun to get to know.  Ralph, despite technically being a villain, is adorable, and it's hard not to empathize with his desire to just be liked and accepted.  Felix, as the hero of a kid's game, is rather hilariously innocent, and actually quite a likeable character -- it would have been too easy for the filmmakers to turn him into the movie's antagonist and make him an ego-driven jerk, but thankfully they avoid that cliche.  Vanellope starts out annoying, but it's hard not to empathize with her desire to fit in and be seen as something other than a "mistake."  And Calhoun, though she falls into the cliche of the battle-hardened soldier with a dark past, manages to be enjoyably snarky, and seems to realize just how out of place she is in the cutesy world of Sugar Rush.This film works on quite a few levels.  It's an enjoyable kids' film (though some moments might be too scary for very young viewers), with enough clever humor and action for adults to be entertained as well.  It's also a loving tribute to retro arcade games, and contains quite a few in-jokes that hardcore gamers will appreciate.  And it also works as a sort of "spiritual successor" to the Toy Story films -- in fact, I wouldn't be surprised if it inhabits the same universe, seeing as its concept, of playthings coming to life in the absence of humans, is quite similar.Wonderful family film, with some friendly nods to the retro and modern gamer crowd.  Highly recommended.P.S.  The theater run of this film included a black-and-white animated short called "Paperman," a sweet and lighthearted cel-shaded CGI feature that's effectively told without dialogue or any color save a hint of red lipstick.  I'm thrilled to see that this will be included in the DVD release.
summary: Finally, a video game movie that's actually GOOD
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: What a great little movie! My husband and I enjoyed watching this so much and we didn't even have an appropriately aged kid as an excuse :) The production quality and storyline are both wonderful. I can't see anyone not liking this film. Its unique and not predictable with lots of great little nods to classic video games throughout.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I really wanted to love Wreck It Ralph. The idea for the story sounded great, the animation was great too. The first half of the movie flowed along well, great character development, but then when he gets over to the Sugar Rush game the momentum of the film grinds down.When it was all said and done I did enjoy the movie, but when the story shifts from being about Ralph to being about Vanellope it took what seemed like a personal growth journey for Ralph and shifted it to being just another animated adventure mixed with MarioKart.If you like the retro games, remember playing Qbert and Beer Tapper, if you love you some beautiful CG, than you should check this out. Wreck It Ralph has good heart, it has a great voice cast, and very subtle humor. I looked forward to watching and wasn't disappointed, but the movie wasn't all that it could have been. Maybe I had too high of hopes being a life long gamer starting in the days of 8-bits and terrible E.T. games so this movie was speaking my language, and I think that may have been my problem, was that it started out as a homage to old video games in a modern world and at some point veered into a standard animated movie. The add in of the old classic video game characters was great, and I loved all the humor and one liners. I just wish the movie stayed on its original line as a goofy classic video game movie about Ralph. I'd never say not to check this movie out but don't expect anything other than nostalgia.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I thought this was really great, it is one of my favorites.  Very imaginative and it was great seeing some of those retro characters from my early childhood come to life again.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Not sure where all these positive reviews are coming from, but this is one boring movie.Starts out reasonably well, but as soon as Sarah Silverman's character is introduced themovie just gets bogged down in story-telling mire. Even John C Reilly, who I like a lotas an actor, seems terribly bored with his role, and voice acting is utterly lifeless --sounds like he's reading a newspaper or texting someone while he's doing Ralph's voice.The animation is spectacular,as you would expect, but it really is wasted on a cliche, draband far too long story. My diagnosis: Skip-it Ralph.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Recommend for family and kids, this is something that doesn't drive me nuts when watching it over and over again.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewerName: Kimberly J. Karas "a New England mom"
reviewText: It's not easy being the bad guy but someone has to do it.  That's Ralph's job, to break things so they game's hero Felix can fix them.  These personable game characters take us into their arcade world and show their roles in the game and how they are all important to one another.  Very appealing to kids who like video games of course and enjoyable for the whole family and all ages.
