Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Disney has made some really good animated movies, but they had never done a lot of movies that are as bright and original as Wreck-it Ralph, the new animated film from Disney. The movie centers on Ralph (voiced by John C. Reilly), the villain in the "Fix-it Felix" arcade game, who decides to become a hero. Because he doesn't like being a bad guy, he goes into some of the video games in order to learn what it's like to become a good guy. He also befriends a character known as Vanellope von Schweetz (voiced by Sarah Silverman) from a candy-coated racing game called "Sugar Rush". When Ralph accidentally unleashes a threat in the arcade, he tries his best to save the day and become a true hero.I had extremely high expectations for this movie. I had the feeling that this will turn out to be an excellent animated film. I thought the premise to this sounded really cool and clever - a love letter to video games. I really love the voice cast.So, did Wreck-it Ralph met my expectations? Absolutely! This was such a fun animated movie for all ages, and better than Disney/PIXAR's Brave (which was also very good).John C. Reilly delivered a strong performance as the title character, who wants to make a change in his life, achieve it, and become what he wants to be. That's what a great movie character is about. Sarah Silverman provides most of the movie's funny moments as one of the "Sugar Rush" characters who Ralph befriends, and is a "glitch" (a character who faults the game). She tries to get Ralph for help to become a racer once again. Jack McBrayer (from the hit-show, 30 Rock) has an amusing supporting role as Fix-it Felix, the main hero in the "Fix-it Felix" arcade game, who sets out to find Ralph and get him back to where he belongs. Jane Lynch does a great job playing the main character in a first-person shooter game known as "Hero's Duty", who tries to find Ralph, alongside Felix.I didn't see the movie in 3D; which I must say it does look pretty darn good in 3D, but I decided to stick with the 2D because of the sharp, pristine screen.The animation is simply wonderful; the bright colors, the set-ups, the environments, the characters all look fantastic. At times, the movie is very gorgeous to look at on the big screen.The characters in this were likable and funny. It was awesome to see some video game characters making cameos (like Bowser, Pac-Man, Sonic, etc.). The story to the movie is well-thought out and genuinely clever. It's always nice to see something new to the table. I really liked the themes to the movie: What does it mean to be a true hero? How can the main character's goal become a success? And so forth.Generally, movies from Disney and/or PIXAR give a lot heart into their stories, which makes the tone of the movie become very sweet. Wreck-it Ralph has enough heart to make it that way. From start to finish, this movie is a lot of fun, and when families bring their kids to see this movie, they're going to fall in love with it.
summary: BRILLIANT! The best animated film of the year!,
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: My wife and boys went to this in the theater.  I wasn't going to go without them, so when I saw it was available the boys and I got down with Ralph and wrecked it!The movie is filled with old school video game characters that made me smile.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Wreck-It Ralph (2012, rated PG) is a fun adventure movie about how an arcade game villain wants to achieve a hero medal. He doesn't want to "go Turbo" (renegade and leave his game); he just wants to not be alone and despised anymore. My parents and grade-school niece didn't understand all the gamer references, but the whole family enjoyed the story, music, and artistry. My sister and I enjoyed the Metal Gear, first-person shooter, Kart, and other references. Wreck-It Ralph has strong voice acting and a well-paced storyline that keeps moving. And some of the puns are great. Younger viewers may find the cy-bugs and final boss scary.
summary: Fun for everyone, gamer or no
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Wreck-it Ralph was a film that dared to dream big.  The premise, according to all the commercials, was about video game characters coming to life when the arcade closes and meeting with one another in their off hours.  In the midst of all this, a video game bad guy named Ralph decides that he's sick of being a villain and wants to become a hero and earn a medal, but where would a big, tough, giant of a man with enormous hands be able to earn a medal?Showcasing Ralph's quest, and the many encounters with characters from -real- video games, the ads for the film promised the story of a strong, powerful protagonist who faces insurmountable odds and achieves his goal of truly getting the recognition that he deserves.  There were also some brief clips of some little, candy brat doing a stupid and un-funny routine where she insults him for no reason, but at worst, we thought, she'll be like Timon and Puumba; a latecomer who's annoying at times, but doesn't disrupt the movie.Big mistake.As I saw it, there were four big factors in this movie; four things that it seemed to be trying to accomplish.1. Ralph's impressiveness as a main character.2. The fun of the journey and the search for the reward.3. The reforming of Ralph into a hero, and the handling of heroism in general in the movie; its moral center.4. The presence and relevance of the other video game characters from other video games.I'm going to be judging the film on its handling of each of these areas, since, when you get down to it, these are the areas in which the movie had a chance to really shine.1. There's no doubt that Ralph had a lot of potential as a hero, and it's been a while since we've seen a hero of his type.  He's 9 feet tall, weighs over 600 lbs, and his fists are larger than his head.  Not only that, but given the length of his arms, this is clearly the sort of bruiser who you don't want to tangle with in a straight-up fight.  Ralph has the potential to be a terrifying enemy, or an incredible hero; a man's man, who gets the job done, and almost threatens to bring the notion back into the public eye, that men can be heroes too.The only question is; how much of this potential was used?  Sadly, the answer is "hardly any."Ralph does get to use his great strength, speed and smashing powers on a semi-regular basis, but as for coming across as a bruiser, or a manly guy, who one might actually want to be like, there's almost none of that here.Ralph is played up, from the very start, as a comedy fall guy.  In his early attempts to acquire a medal, he blunders around, panics, trips, falls, gets yelled at, sets off traps and activates dozens of deadly enemy bug-eggs.  Still, these things can happen, even to a very impressive hero.Unfortunately, Ralph's personality is done little better.  He's portrayed largely as an unthreatening, sitcom oaf, who has his desires and all that, but never needs to be taken too seriously, and sure enough, the other characters don't take him seriously at all.  He complains about not getting cake, whines when he's stopped by the embodiment of a surge protector, and generally acts sad and mopey over his lot in life, and even when he decides to take action, it's done in more of a "ah-ha!  I have a plan!" way, rather than demonstrating real, strong determination to change his life.However, perhaps the worst thing about Ralph's presentation as the main character is that he's really -not- the main character.  That honor is reserved for Vanilly... Vanelly...  Sarah Silverman, who plays a bratty little girl from a candyland-inspired slot car racing game called "Sugar Rush," (which, like "Fix-it Felix Jr," Ralph's game, is not a real game at all.)  About a third of the way into the movie, Ralph finds himself in Sugar Rush, and then that's pretty much it.  The part of the movie that you wanted to see, about Ralph struggling to attain his goal and being a cool main character is pretty much over.The Sarah Silverman character steals Ralph's medal and runs off, trouncing and outdoing him in climbing, running and pretty much everything else with embarrassing ease.  Try to imagine your favorite baseball player getting up to bat, and being just -utterly humiliated- by a five-year-old girl with a squeaky voice, who thinks she's funny, and isn't.  As spacious as Ralph's faults may be, he's still supposed to be the main character, and we don't want to see this done to him.However, you'd better get used to it.  Sarah Silverman continues humiliating Ralph.  She's annoying and bratty, never learns a single lesson of any value, and yet, the director wants us to believe she's always right.  Sarah Silverman is annoying, even when she's -not- saddled with this kind of role.  Frankly, the whole thing from this point on made me wince, particularly since we're apparently supposed to start caring about her, and want her to succeed, even though she's already proven that she's a liar and a thief, and doesn't care about Ralph -at all.-  No.  Just no.  This movie fails to make Ralph an impressive, manly main character, because he's not nearly as impressive as he should be, comes off as more oafish than manly, and isn't even the main character.2. Is the journey any fun?  Are we excited to see whether or not Ralph will get his reward?  Well, no.  Not really.  Even at the start, Ralph's motives for wanting the medal are a little materialistic and unsatisfying.  He seems less concerned with being appreciated than with medals, and cakes and penthouses; things that you can touch.  His reasons for going on the quest just felt too physical to me.  It's not like Aladdin, who wants to be treated as more than just street scum, or Belle, who wants some excitement and something transcendent;  beyond her normal life.  These are purely material desires, and frankly, I can't sympathize.As I said, Ralph tends to panic and flee when he's confronted with difficult and dangerous circumstances, which puts a massive damper on the excitement and fun of the quest.  You might as well just admit that Ralph; whatever his potential, isn't much of a hero at this point, and of course, a fun quest that does not make.If it's not fun at -that- stage, it's certainly a great deal -less- fun when Sarah Silverman is introduced, and the movie takes a hard left turn away from the quest that it was supposed to be about.  Eventually, it's completely forgotten.Now, this is not necessarily a bad thing.  In many movies, the initial motivation is for riches, or power, or recognition, and the character ultimately learns that these are not as important as family and happiness, and doing the right thing.  All well and good.The problem is that in -this- movie, what replaces the medal is -not- good, wholesome values, but just Ralph's desire to be "liked" by Sarah Silverman, and doing things that will make her feel better.  This is a problem for two reasons.  1. Being liked is not a virtue.  2. Doing things that make people feel better is not a virtue.  This movie replaces shallow materialism with the slightly-less-shallow motive of wanting to be liked by at least one person.  A fun quest that does not make.3. What is the moral center of the movie?  Is Ralph a hero?  Is he made into a hero, and does he reform?  Is this a story of a person reforming from their evil ways?Well, no.  It's not.  The premise of the film is that all characters in video games are essentially actors playing roles.  Therefore, the heroes are often not terribly heroic, and the villains not terribly villainous, once you catch them off-duty.  Therefore, no real reforming needs to be done.  Ralph isn't a -real- villain.  He just plays one on TV.Of course, this raises several questions.  Why do the hero and the NPCs treat Ralph like an outcast outside of work hours?  Isn't that -actually- evil?  I mean, he didn't do anything wrong.  He just did what he was supposed to do; wreck the building, so Felix could fix it.  Ralph was just doing what he was hired (essentially) to do.  The reaction of the NPCs is essentially elitism on the basis of the pre-determined caste system that was programmed into them, and ultimately, that makes them the real bad guys for most of the movie.Strangely, many of the other video game villains seem similar to Ralph in that sense; not horrible people; just actors doing their jobs.Here's the problem.  Throughout the entire movie, they continue using the word "bad" to mean "the role of villain in a game," and "good" to mean "the role of hero in a game," and that is -not- what those words mean.  I almost got the impression that the movie was trying to imply that -real- good and evil were as insubstantial as the roles that one plays in the acting profession, which is just a total rejection of the most basic foundations of all true knowledge.  It's a false as false can be.This aspect of the film really comes to a head when Ralph performs a truly heroic act near the movie's end, while reciting the "bad guy affirmation," about how he'll never be "good," and the only thing he wants to be is himself.  If there is one line that can utterly kill the substance of an act of heroic self-sacrifice on the part of a main character, this is it.In the end, of course, people start to appreciate Ralph a little more, and treat him a little better, but through it all, the substance of -real- good and evil is lost in the dust.  Heroism is demonstrated, but not addressed, and the movie's moral core seems to aim, rather, at a sort of Hollywood, rich-people, anti-moralism than any sort of actual moral message that a kid could understand or benefit from.4. That brings us to the final area on which this movie should be judged; the video game characters who make appearances.  I got the impression that this movie wanted to emulate "Who Framed Roger Rabbit," which had a lot of guest-appearances by other characters from other cartoons, from Bugs Bunny to Mickey Mouse.  This is, in fact, the aspect of the film that's showcased most in the trailers; the video game guest stars, but I hope you enjoyed those trailers, because they covered -nearly all- of the guest appearances by real game characters in this movie.The bad guy meeting has a bunch of guest characters, then there are the brief scenes in game central station, and a scene in the Tapper video game.  Q-bert and his pals show up in a few more scenes, but aside from those, that's pretty much all the guest appearances you'll see, most of which, as I said, are in the film's first third, before the Sugar Rush debacle.Yes, it's charming to see these characters rendered in 3D.  Yes, it's fun to see them in a high-profile movie.  However, they don't act like the characters in the games, because they're not.  They're just actors playing roles.  As for the rest, it's a minor thrill with little or no substance behind it.  I got that thrill from the trailers, but the film had little to offer after that in this area.The other aspect that I thought would be a mainstay of the plot was traversing one video game world after another in Ralph's quest.  Guess how many he travels to.  Go ahead.  Guess.Two.Ralph goes to the bad guy meeting in the Pac-Man game, though it just looks like a blank room during the scene itself.  He then spends two scenes in the video game "Tapper," where he drinks and talks to Tapper about his problems.  Apart from this, none of the worlds that Ralph visits are based off real video games, except for Fix-it Felix Jr itself, which I'm not going to count, because it's just an online game that was made to promote the film.  I'm not counting that.The only other worlds that Ralph visits are Hero's Duty and Sugar Rush, and there are no games for those.  You will never play Hero's Duty.  You will never play Sugar Rush.  They don't exist, and they never will.Roger Rabbit was a multi, mega cartoon crossover masterpiece, and a darn good story in its own right, and that's what Wreck-it Ralph could have been.  A multi, mega, video game crossover masterpiece, and a darn good story in its own right.  However, it sank its own story when it decided to be about Sarah Silverman, rather than an awesome, heroic title character, and it's certainly not the massive video game crossover that the ads suggest.ConclusionIn the final analysis, this movie fails or does poorly on nearly every level.  It's not -that bad- compared to some recent animated films, allegedly for kids, but this says more about the state of modern children's entertainment than it does about Wreck-it Ralph.  I give it a nearly halfway grade for this reason, but I have to be honest here; I consider this film to be a major disappointment.  It seemed to have great promise, and whatever else you can say about it, you can't say it made good on that promise.
summary: Unbeknownst to the audience, we've secretly replaced the main character with Sarah Silverman
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: A nice fun movie to watch with the family. I enjoyed all the video game references of the past, my childhood.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: A movie the whole family really liked.  The only questionable part, for younger children, was very close to the end when the characters meet the villain in his true form.  My 5 year old was a little scared during that part, but only remembers the fun parts of the movie.  Also, a trip down memory lane for us who grew up in the 80s with the video games.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The movie was funny and entertaining for the whole family.  We were unable to make it to the movie theater when this was out and we wanted to see it.  It was enjoyable.  Truly a family movie.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Disney puts out another cute movie!  I love the obvious kid theme and morals being shown, as well as some of the humor meant for adults. Good movie. :)
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: First of all, let me say that neither I, nor my eight-year old son felt the need to finish the movie though the other three kids enjoyed it and my husband might rate it a three just because of the video game nostalgia it generated.  The storyline seemed to be a mash-up of all three "Toy Story" movies, "Shrek" and "Up".  The characters were annoying as were their voices, though I did like John C. Reilly's voice for Ralph. The humor was weak and inconsistent.  We rented it from Amazon Prime and have no plans to buy the DVD. Please, Disney, tell me you are not going to fall back into the dark ages of the late 20th/early 21st century, when you thought "Brother Bear", "Treasure Planet" and "Atlantis" were all good ideas!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Do you like video games? Old and new? Do you root for the bad guy sometimes?  Do you like love stories?  Do you like cute girls, cars, racing, and candy?  If so this is for you!A great movie for kids through grandparents - as long as they've played a few video games along the way!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Simply nothing to not like here if you enjoy gorgeous colors and good laughs. And if you were addicted to Donkey Kong and Space Invaders and Asteroids in 1981 like me, then you will be in retro heaven. The concept is pure creativity, the script is tight and the voices are excellent, especially O'Reilly, who is far beyond most voice actors. He really brings Ralph to life. Yet the image quality is what takes center stage.Up was the finest animated blu-ray image I've seen until this, but the deep deep colors and incredibly varied hues here combine with the crazily detailed images to produce eye candy of another dimension, like the recent Speed Racer movie but much finer in every way. The sound is also pristine, total clarity and nice crisp stereo detail.All in all, one of the most non-stop fun toons I've ever seen. The only thing missing was Roger Rabbit! Absolutely recommended in every way, especially if you want to laugh in amazement while seeing just how incredible your flat screen can look. The fact that the movie is so well made is just icing on this sweet sugar rush of a flick.
summary: Phenomenal eye candy, ingenious story, state of the art blu-ray image
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Seriously, think of all the really bad movies that are based off of video games, there's a ton. This movie not only blows them out of the water but actually manages to make a great original story at the same time.As a gamer who remembers just about every game mentioned (saw my childhood flash before me in the opening arcade montage) this movie manages to capture that fun of what a video game is all about. Not to mention makes you wonder just how you'd like doing the same job over and over again for 30 years.It's got the laugh for the kids and nostalgia for us mid-30 types who remember all this stuff.
summary: Best Video game movie ever made

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The concept behind this is cute - Ralph is tired of being the bad guy in a video game, and wants to go into another game in the arcade to earn a medal as a hero, and finally get some praise for a change. He actually does do this, but unfortunately it's in a shooting oriented game featuring automatic rifles, and since this is a film for young kids, I just don't get that. My kids (ages 8 and 6) have not yet been exposed to gun games, and while I'm sure they will eventually, I just don't see why that had to be part of the plot in an animated film made for young children. The other games featured are oriented around racing, sports, or Ralph wrecking a building, and they could have just stuck with that and a few other less violent themed games.Anyway, putting that aside, this would have been a 4 to 5 star film for me. It's a creative idea, and I appreciated the fact it hasn't been done before. There's a lot of funny moments, for adults and kids, and the video theme allows for some fun animation. The emotional heart of the film is well-intentioned, with themes of friendship, loyalty, and helping others emphasized.BUT I just couldn't get past the automatic rifles. I know this film was made pre-Newtown, but still, show some sense, Hollywood!
summary: Cute Concept and Funny, But Were the Guns Really Necessary?
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewerName: Lorenzo M. in the Hollywood CA Area "Movie Wa...
reviewText: Remember the old video games in the arcades of the 80's? They are incredibly represented here and in a very fun way. The film does have a middle section that was slow and a little off track, but with that said, `Wreck It Ralph' does have a fantastic opening and definitely a surprising and eventfully fun ending! The animation is very sharp and extremely real. (Not phot-real, but artistically real.)`Wreck It Ralph' is director Richard Moore's (Futurama, Drawn Together) first feature film coming from a broad television animation background. Taking a script from Phil Johnston (Cedar Rapids, Ghost/Aliens) and first time writer Jennifer Lee, Richard mixed a great deal of personality types and funny creative situations inside of a video game and the world they live in.The games you see in this film are all familiar to those who remember the stand-up, giant boxed TV sets you used to look down at and play your games with. The graphics were simple and the music very distinct with each game environment along with all the sound effects that only came from the 80`s. I had lots of memories of all the games!John C Reilly (Chicago, Magnolia) leads the cast as `Wreck It Ralph' himself who has the odd job of being the villain in his game. Alone, mistreated and often misunderstood he decides to get some recognition by getting an award. With the help of the hysterical Jane Lynch (Glee, 40 Year-Old Virgin) as demanding and pushy militaristic leader of grunts, Calhoun, Ralph gets a little miss directed and off course ending up in many strange games, but none are his own.Now `Wreck It Ralph' has a star in its game called Felix, voiced so sympathetically and humorously dry by Jack McBrayer (30 Rock, Forgetting Sarah Marshall). Jack's innocence and sincerity make the movie so much more fun to watch. I loved observing his take on growing a `fancy' for Jane Lynch's  Calhoun character and how slowly they realize they might just work together, as a couple.Ralph enters a game, wrongly of course, that is based a Candyland-type environment, and accidently bumps into and later, begrudgingly, befriends a small `glitch' in the program who is named Venellope, voiced amazingly perfect by Sarah Silverman (Something About Mary, School Of Rock) . She is independent, stubborn, obnoxious, not responsible and wildly out of hand, but seems to be sweet and sincere enough for Ralph to help.A special note to Alan Tudyk (Firefly, I, Robot), who plays King Candy and does an amazingly unique impression of what might be consider `The Mad Hatter' with his own twist. Alan gives such fun and flair and craziness to his candy obsessed royalty.Without giving too much away, the movie has a fun concept of group therapy for bad guys, an inventive concept on how game characters travel from one game to another and a clever plot concept on how games need to understand, they all need each other. I also loved the great detail and 3-D stylization they used to represent the accuracy of how all these old games really moved and operated.  `Wreck It Ralph' has a great family message in the really funny and creative world of 80's video games. This is great light family fun!
summary: Wreck It Ralph Is Fun, Clever and Downright Inventive!

reviewText: This movie was laugh-out-loud amazing. Ralph is a villain tired of doing the villain-thing, and ventures into other games to prove himself. Along the way he runs into a rambunctious little girl who is a "glitch", and together they learn from each other and become better people, accepting their "flaws" and growing stronger. I'm usually the one to root for the underdog, or be intrigued by the villain and their life story, so this movie was right up my alley. I'm also a big Sonic the Hedgehog fan, so it was a bonus to see him every now-and-then throughout the movie!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: "Wreck-It Ralph" is for video games, what "Toy Story" was for toys; a fantastic movie which entertains the younger audiences, and makes the older ones nostalgic; wishing for their childhood to return.  At the core of this animated work is a story that never fails to make me reach for the box of Kleenex. Ralph's endless campaign for some recognition, and self-worth is a theme that would resonate with anyone.  The loneliness he suffers tugs at the heart strings and makes you yearn for Ralph's happily ever after.  I was quite surprised at the complex story themes found in "Wreck-It Ralph", although given Disney's propensity for creating heart-warming and emotionally gratifying stories, I am not sure why I was so surprised.  Perhaps it was because the story takes place in a world populated with classic video game characters. I didn't think that I could feel warm and fuzzy inside while watching a movie in which M. Bison, Zangief, Smoke, Kano, Bowser, and Sonic the Hedgehog can be seen front and center.  Yet the themes of individuality, trust, friendship, and self-sacrifice never fail to make one hell of a story.  Wreck-It Ralph is truly a work of art and deserves a place in everyone's video library.  Well done Disney!  Well done indeed!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: ....of a video game character. Wreck it Ralph is surprisingly original with its cast of video game regulars as the stars. Dr. Robotnik in group therapy...Who would have thought it? The movie itself, however, does explore universal themes like self esteem, bullying, friendship, pesky bugs, and dealing with people whose need to be in power and control gets out of control. The movie is funny too and I love Jane Lynch's character. Her "take no prisoners" and so-long to kitten whixkers' approach cracks me up.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Pretty cute movie. Clean story (no innuendos that would be concerning if a young child watched it). It was pretty funny and the story line was unique.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I took my family to see this when it was first in the theaters, and had no expectations for it, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. The story is about a character in a video arcade game who plays the "bad guy" in the game, but after work hours (when the video game is not in use), he just wants to be a regular guy and be friends with the other characters. He joins a "bad guy" self-help group for some support (think AA), which is very funny, but then decides he needs to become a hero to gain some respect. All the arcade games are connected electrically through the same power strip, and in this movie, characters can move between games through this connection (although they aren't supposed to). Ralph decides to sneak into a military game temporarily so he can become a "hero", but things inevitably go wrong there and he ends up in a candy-land auto race game aimed at young girl arcade players. Most of the adventure takes place within this game, and it is quite funny, with a redeeming ending. As with many of the most recent Disney animations, there are unexpected (but not stupid) character twists and turns, with a plot that holds your interest (I am an adult, after all), and with smart humor and no talking down to the audience (us). It was a pleasant way to spend an hour-and-a-half.I purchased the Blu-ray version of this movie which has three discs: 3-D, regular Blu-ray, and DVD. I have a 50" 3-D TV and a 3-D Blu-ray player; I don't use the 3-D capability much, but I did try this movie out in 3-D. I saw it in the theater in regular 2-D, so I can't compare the experience, but the 3-D seemed good and not distracting. Did it add anything to the overall movie experience? Not really. If the story is good, it's good in 2-D and 3-D, and this is a good story. Note that the colors are actually more vibrant when watching it in 2-D. The sound on the Blu-ray discs (either one) is in DTS surround sound, and it is great. I personally feel that a decent surround sound experience enhances a movie at home way more than 3-D does (I have to admit, though, I saw Disney's "Frozen" in the theater in 3-D and it was awesome, but you definitely need the giant theater screen for that).Oh, I also recently purchased the "Frozen" Blu-ray (not in 3-D), and I enjoyed watching it at home as much as in the theater. As I said, a good story is a good story.
summary: Very good Disney movie, fun for kids and adults

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Extraordinarily engaging animated film!And unlike the recent disappointments of 'ParaNorman' or 'Tron: Legacy', the creators of 'Wreck It' have the right idea - recognizing that a complex presentation will deliver an infinitely more satisfying product than simply recycling old ideas and throwing a shiny new wrapper around it.Tells the story of video game characters whose existence is much more than anyone suspects. When the humans leave the arcade center, it's revealed that they're actually alive; their world just as real as ours and much grander than what we see thru the fixed limitation of the game screen consoles.The movie centers on one particular video villain named Wreck-It Ralph whose simple pixelated existence is to break down an apartment building, while his nemesis and hero namesake of the game is Fix-It Felix Jr., the squeaky clean goodie-two-shoes who goes about repairing Ralph's two-fisted destruction. Up to the point where Felix cheerfully gathers the apartment residents into an angry mob and tossing the big guy off the roof into a dirty pool of mud.As the years pass, Ralph settles into this depressing life with no friends or family. His so-called home a literal dump made up of destroyed bricks from the job, eating food that's thrown out by the apartment residents, and sleeping in the open like some mistreated mongrel dog. His only comfort, and it's a limited one at that, is finding refuge at BadAnon - a support group for fellow villains, who, it turns out are anything but villainous.Desperate for change, any change, he embarks on obtaining the one thing a bad guy is not suppose to receive - a gold medal. It's a hugely symbolic token that Fix-It Felix receives every day and with every play of the game. Frustrated beyond even his sizable tolerance, Ralph will break from tradition and hopefully change everyone's perspective; focusing on who he is and not what his label says.But the one absolute no-no of the video game world, the one unbreakable code, is to never "Go Turbo". A reference to an old game character who literally went crazy, left his own malfunctioning game, invaded another and got caught. Human patrons playing the invaded game complained and both consoles were unplugged = electronic death.As Ralph embarks on his incredible journey across a variety of video environments in search of a gold medal, he discovers much more than he ever dreamed - or feared - was possible.Again, an absolutely wonderful, exciting, and fun film for all ages. The perfect blend of wonderful CGI, incredibly rich storytelling, and a touching tip-of-the-hat to the collective history of video games and its earliest fans.Personal Note:- This film seems like the penultimate descendant to those early 1930s cartoons, like "Have You Got Any Castles?", where characters from books came to life and interacted with one another.- Absolutely loved the first gen video characters making cameo appearances. Tender and warmly nostalgic moments when guys like Qbert, Clyde, and The Joust Knight have a last chance to once again shine in the public spotlight. Classy.- Jane Lynch = Combat Babe. Yeehaw!  X-D
summary: Absolutely Wonderful, Clever, and Just Fun
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This review is based on taking my family to see "Wreck-it Ralph" in the cinema in 3D.My 11 year old daughter summed this film up in the words "Tell them that it was really funny and very clever," and for once her twin brother agreed with her, describing the film in one word, "Epic!" My wife and I also enjoyed the film which works on a lot of subtle levels.As in the original "Tron (Original Classic) [1982] [DVD]" film, most of the characters are video game characters. The story is set in a games arcade, and "Wreck it Ralph" is the villain in the longest running game in the arcade, "Fix it Felix." Ralph (voiced by John C. Reilly) is the opponent who wrecks things: he has to try to knock down buildings faster than the hero of the game, Felix (voiced by Jack McBrayer), can mend them with his magic hammer.At the start of the film, Ralph is telling his story at a meeting of the support group for video game villains, "Bad Anon." When the arcade is closed, the game isn't running and all the characters in the game are living their own secret lives in the same way that, for example, characters in the "Toy Story (Blu-ray 3D)" films do when their kids are not around. Ralph is fed up with the fact that for thirty years he has not just been the villain in the game itself, but is treated like one by the "Niceland" characters when they're not all playing the game.At a party to celebrate thirty years of "Fix it Felix," Ralph, provoked by one insult too many, vows that he will win a medal to prove that he can be a hero. So he visits a new game for older children/young adults, a first-person shooter called "Hero's Duty" where the good guys, under the command of the beautiful and very tough Sergeant Calhoun (voiced by Jane Lynch from "Glee: The Complete First Season"), have to battle the evil Cy-Bugs.Ralph's quest for a medal takes him next to an racing arcade game for very small children called "Sugar Rush" where he meets the ruler of the game, "King Candy" voiced by Alan Tudyk (Wash from "Serenity [DVD] [2005]" and "Firefly - The Complete Series [DVD] [2003] and Sonny in "I, Robot [Blu-ray] (2004).") Here Ralph runs afoul of a charming little girl called Vanellope who wants to take part in the race but is banned from doing so because she is regarded by the other characters as a "glitch" or mistake in the game's programming.But there are several things which are amiss in the world of "Sugar Rush." Ralph's attempts to gain a medal have unwittingly threatened the existence of his own game and several others, if not the entire arcade.King Candy warns Ralph that his actions could easily result in the customers reporting that "Sugar Rush" has a fault, which might possibly lead to the closure of the game. Ralph's absence has forced the arcade's owner to declare the "Fix It Felix" game out of order because when Ralph is not there to knock holes in the buildings, Felix has nothing to fix. To avert the permanent closure of the game, Felix comes looking for him, joined by Sergeant Calhoun, who realises that Ralph has unwittingly unleashed the most serious threat of all, one which could easily destroy first the game and world of "Sugar Rush" and then go on to threaten every character and game in the arcade.Two of these threats are genuine, the third is a plausible and clever trick. In the process of defeating the real threats, Ralph has to learn what is really required of a true hero ...All the best family films work on more than one level, with one set of jokes and challenges to entertain the kids and another set for the grown ups. This film managed this far better than most. Several of the characters in the game - particularly Sergeant Calhoun but she's not the only one - manage to have a dual focus. Calhoun is  simultaneously steeped in the tragic backstory of the game, which is completely real to her, making her intensely dedicated to stopping the deadly menace of the "Cy-bugs" she is fighting, and yet also well aware that her world is a game which must be made entertaining to the customers so they will keep playing it and that world will not be switched off by the arcade management. One of the iconic exchanges in the film is when she asks Wreck-it Ralph,"Do you know what the first rule of Hero's Duty is, soldier?"When Ralph replies "No cuts, no buts, no coconuts?"she icily informs him that the correct answer is that you do NOT "interfere with the first person shooter" (e.g. you don't get the player "killed.")The way in which characters in games written for players of very different ages interacted was brilliantly done, and the film made you care about the characters to a far greater degree than I would have thought possible. There were also a great many moments which were laugh-out-loud funny.We're so used these days to seeing fantasy worlds brought to life in a way which looks real that we rarely notice it, but the quality of the visual effects in this film was excellent.I can recommend this film as a treat for kids of all ages.
summary: Brilliant family film about a video game villain who wants to be the hero

reviewText: Very rarely do I enjoy a movie as much as I enjoyed this one, and for good reason. This movie was superbly put together and the idea of video game characters having a world of their own was executed really well in this film. I only wish that Megaman and Dr. Wily had been included in this, but there are plenty of other characters from iconic games such as Pac-Man, Sonic the Hedgehog, and etc, along with several made-up video games. The ending of this movie was also really good, and the storyline itself rather believable. Absolutely fantastic, if I could give this movie ten stars, I very well would!

reviewText: WRECK IT RALPH has a lot going for it.  It's visually impressive, has a good voice cast, especially John C. Reilly, Sarah Silverman and Jane Lynch.  As with most Disney animation, there's a strong moral message lurking beneath the frivolous activities.  So why do I feel less enthused than most of my fellow reviewers?It seems a little lengthy and tedious; there's nothing really new going on and it's a fairly predictable film.  Both kids and adults should find it enjoyable----I just find it ordinary, a film I will easily forget.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I was a teen in the 80s. The explosion of the video game arcade was in full swing, and this movie really brings me back to those good ol' coin-op days. My daughter (10) enjoyed it as an original movie but at a totally different level than I. I was familiar with many of the video game characters, and I thought Disney's take on this was really smart (Pixar-like, in terms of story). Sure, some of it was predictable and over-the-top, but the blu-ray version shines with its radiant color and crisp soundtrack. Voice-acting was quite good as well.For adults who lived through the 80s and played a coin-op video game or two, you will get more out of this movie than you think…and your kids/grandkids will enjoy it without having known the classic video game characters.
summary: This adult enjoyed it on a whole other level
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Finding NEMO, CARS, Monster Inc. These are a few of Pixar/Disney releases that are better. IMHO. I may be partially at fault for this rating though. I have read many reviews of this movie and several critics praised this as one of the best ever. So of course I was expecting this amazing movie towering over other Pixar releases. SIGH. The story is uncomplicated to a point that the whole movie could have been done as a half hour cartoon with commercials. None of the characters grab you as truly memorable. The previews give the impression that Ralph goes on some epic journey and he only really visits 2 other games (if you don't count the bar), and a major portion of the movie is in a single game. While other Pixar movies seem to be designed for the young and old alike to enjoy, Wreck-it Ralph is just a kids movie. The bug war part that is directed towards the older crowd is so minimum in movie time, there's almost a "stick this in for the teens" feel to it. Its decent animation and very colorful but is below par overall for what I have come to expect from Pixar. 3 stars is as far as I'll go on this one.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I've been planning on seeing "Wreck-It Ralph" since the first trailer came out featuring Talking Heads' "Once in a Lifetime."  It was a clear message to Gen Xers that this was a movie for us.  The fact that it happened to be released shortly after my birthday made it a perfect opportunity to take my son to his first movie.  When we got there it was clear I wasn't the only one - there were several dads with their children in the theater."Wreck-It Ralph" posits the question: does Donkey Kong like his job? When you make a living being a bad guy, does that make you a BAD guy? It's a timeworn plot that worked well for "The Incredibles" and "Monsters, Inc." - the plight of modern men who are becoming increasingly dissatisfied with their lot in life.  In this case it's Ralph (John C. Reilly) who has a love/hate relationship with the people who live in the building he regularly wrecks and the hero who rebuilds it, Felix (Jack McBrayer).  Despondent over his unpopularity and low social status, Ralph decides to strive for a medal in another game with visions of returning home as a hero.That game is Hero's Duty, a cross between Call of Duty and Halo. It's there that Ralph gets mixed up with tough-but-vulnerable Calhoun (Jane Lynch).  Ralph only gradually begins to understand just how much he has unbalanced the natural order of the video game universe when he ends up contaminating a racing game called Sugar Rush."Wreck-It Ralph" is a sly nod to the 80s heyday of coin-operated console video games, when characters had lovable quirks like speaking a nonsensical language (Q-bert), limited movement (Felix), or served beer as a form of entertainment (Tapper). At various points during the film, we see the action from a two-dimensional pixilated perspective.  This puts the film in the right frame - it's all just pixels for our entertainment, after all."Wreck-It Ralph" is not without its flaws.  There's a tedious romance between Felix and Calhoun, complete with flashbacks, that could have easily been excised.  The majority of the movie actually focuses on the hyper-adorable Vanellope (Sarah Silverman) in Sugar Rush, a setting which is more Candy Kingdom (from Adventure Time) than a video game -- adults looking for a heady whirl through other gamescapes will be disappointed.  Mostly, it's just too long, and all the kids in the audience got fidgety whenever there was too much dialogue.The moral of the story seems to be that the job market is tough, your role is more important than you think, and you're better off being appreciated in your old job than going for glory in your new one.  Or maybe I'm simply reading too much into it.  My son thought the movie was "okay," but then he's never played Pac-Man or Donkey Kong.
summary: Does Donkey Kong like his job?

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The is the most enjoyable animated movie Disney has made since they switched from traditional to CGI. As a long time gamer and a dad, there is a lot to like about Wreck-It Ralph. There are references and in-jokes galore that will delight gamers, and plenty of colorful and fun characters that will delight children of all ages. The story itself is very well done, too. I genuinely liked and cared about all the characters. The animation is some of the best I've seen from Disney, and I really like that each character and world has it's own look and style. Characters from an 8-bit game move and act differently than characters from a next-gen HD game. Every moment in Wreck-It Ralph is filled with the kind of attention to detail that comes from a genuine love of your work, and it's clear this crew loved making this movie.The thing that surprised me about Wreck-It Ralph is that the story is so engaging, and there were a few twists and surprises that I didn't see coming. The movie has heart, and it doesn't feel shoehorned in. I was also happy to see that the nerdy game references were accurate. As a gamer, it's annoying to see movies that attempt to make references to video games, but fail. Even if you're not a gamer, the movie is still great, and the story is solid enough that anyone can enjoy it, gamer or not. The music is perfect, with a mix of chip-tunes, orchestral, techno, and generally video game appropriate music. The voice acting is also great, with all the actors fitting the roles well. Sometimes celebrity voices sound out of place (like Adam Sandler in Hotel Transylvania), but that's not the case here.The Blu-ray looks fantastic. The images are crisp, the details sharp. The color is vivid without feeling over-saturated. Of all the Blu-rays I've seen, Disney Blu-rays have always looked the best. The sound is in 7.1 HD Master audio, and although I don't have a 7.1 system, I do have a nice external 2.0 stereo system, and it sounds great. Everything is clear, and all the dialogue is audible. One thing I don't like is Blu-rays that have a really wide mix, where music and loud sound effects are 100x louder than the dialogue. Here, the mix is fantastic, and the quiet parts are never too quiet, and the loud parts are never deafeningly loud. I'd give the audio/video of this Blu-ray an A+.One thing I would have liked to see is more special features. There is a short "making of" feature where they talk about the challenges of creating distinct world for each of the games in the move, and a little bit about designing the characters, but there is no mention of the voice cast, and no coverage of the fantastic music. If you pause the movie, an "intermission" features starts that tells you about little hidden "easter eggs" in the movie, hosted by gaming nerd Chris Hardwick. This is probably my favorite, as I am a fan of Hardwick's. There's also the short film "Paperman", which is beautiful, and won an Oscar. Beyond that, there's just the usual trailers and crap. I would have liked to see more in-depth features covering more aspects of making the movie, but maybe I'm just being greedy. Overall, what is here, the movie and the special features, is solid and is well worth your money.In short, go buy this movie. It is fantastic, and I can't think of a single reason you won't like it.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Disney Studios have come out with another attempt to get something like a "Toy Story" franchise with this loud and colorful film for kids.  Even an old fuddy-duddy like me can still appreciate well told stories with animated characters as long as there are some jokes for the oldsters and a good musical score.Our hero is actually a "bad guy" named Ralph (John C. Reilly) who resides within the arcade game called Fix-It Felix Jr.  His job is to wreck an apartment while Felix Jr. (Jack McBrayer) repairs the destruction with his magic hammer.  Ralph is tired of being ostracized by Felix and the apartment's residents.  He is told that in order to fit in he needs to win a gold medal.Ralph decides he wants to be a "good guy" and goes to another game in search of the medal which he accidentally does win.  He is chastised however by the hero of that game, a warrior named Calhoun (Jane Lynch) because he allowed a small mechanical spider-like creature go with him to yet another game.  In this Candy Land game he meets a young girl named Vanellope (Sarah Silverman) who is also shunned by others in the game because she is known as a glitch, which eventually could shut down the game for good.The story must resolve itself as Felix, Calhoun, Vanellope and Ralph work to correct a wrong perpetrated by King Candy (Alan Tudyk).  Oh and destroy the spider-thingies who have grown and multiplied.  The film looks great on Blu ray 1080p and has a thunderous DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 sound option.  As far as the jokes and music?  Nothing special, although I admit that some of the jokes involving the arcade games sailed over my head.  The conclusion of the movie was very good but it took a while to get rolling.  I suspect that the younger viewers will enjoy the movie without reservation.
summary: 3 1/2 stars for visual entertainment aimed at kids
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This is a story of a villain who dreams of being a good guy, but he is only a program in a video game arcade.  One day he decides to leave his game to win a medal in a different game and winds up in a third game.  In the third game, Sugar Rush, he winds up encountering a whole new set of challenges to re-win his medal and perhaps his good/bad guy status.Throughout the bulk of the film, lighthearted humor is present.  While there are a number of conflicts the characters must work through, it is interesting and entertaining to see how they work out and through in video game land.Definitely a fun film.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This movie was just kind of adorable. Having played the original video games (Pong was a big deal back in the stone age) I could not resist checking this out and I wasn't disappointed with this homage to the old guys.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This review is for the content of the single disc DVD and not the plot of the movie (which is awesome).Disney seems to not care about consumers who want only the DVD and don't have Blu-Ray players or wish to avoid overpaying for combo packs or diamond editions. They also release single DVDs about a month after Blu-Ray to trick you into paying more.  In years past, Disney issued two disc dvds with loads of extras and wonderful artwork on the actual discs. Now you just get a bare bones, generic gray disc with the title in unimpressive font. As a lover of physical discs, it's quite disappointing that this seems to be a generic throw away disc.There is not a single extra on this DVD.  It contains the movie and the animated short "Paper Man" but not one single solitary behind the scenes look.  The movie itself is awesome but you are robbed of the pleasure of seeing behind the scenes interviews with the creators or ant interesting presentations of them unless you want to pay double for a combo pack (Blu Ray DVD and Digital copy), which is three versions of the same movie.This is the most disappointing new release DVD from Disney yet.  I dislike being fed DVD scraps because I don't want to overpay for a combo pack.  Give us SOMETHING Disney!You do get your Disney Magic Code if you buy it new, but you only get 100 pts.
summary: Single Disc Has No Extras. Very Bare Bones.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: A very clever premise: Arcade game characters that travel through the cords to mingle when the arcade closes. A bad guy who doesn't want to be the bad guy all the time. The progress of video games from 8-bit graphics to high def. A villain who looks and sounds just like Disney's Mad Hatter (great voice). The story itself is good but not brilliant. It's mostly the humanity John C. Reilly brings to the part. He gives us the real perspective of the frustrations of always having to be the bad guy. The little girl got to be too annoying at times, but overall the movie worked well.
summary: John C. Reilly brings humanity to the bad guy
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Animation is at it's best showing worlds, objects, and action that cannot be realized any other way.  Anybody who was obsessed with video games as a kid will like this movie. I would have instantly bought a DVD titled "Ralph and Q-bert Save Candyland" or even "Q-bert Rescues Sarah Silverman."
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: For years, video game based movies are always been horrible from Super Mario Bros to Doom, it seems that Hollywood could not adapt the awesomeness of video games to the silver screen and many people are pre-disposed to dismiss video game based movies as garbage until this time, while technically Wreck-It Ralph is not a real game, it was made for the movie, it seems that all we needed was an original story to get it right.Wreck-It Ralph is a movie about misunderstood and unappreciated Wreck it Ralph, the bad guy from Fix-It Felix, jr. After attending a bad guy support group meeting and being shunned from the 30th anniversary party for his game, Ralph is determined to win a medal and some respect for his part in the game. The movie features many cameos from classic video games, a warm and touching story filled with action and eye popping graphics, this is a perfect movie for the family or date night (guys, if your girlfriend is not into games, let her watch this movie with you and she will have a better appreciation for  your hobby).The ultimate collector's edition comes with a Blu-ray, DVD, 3D version and digital copy, included is the short "Paperman" which was shown to open the movie, it is also a short and sappy story about a plain guy who meets a young woman (who looks like Anne Hathaway) and some hijinks involving paper airplanes leads them to a chance encounter, very nice. Deleted scenes and bonus documentaries round out the extras and worth a look.The visuals and sound are outstanding in Blu-ray, I watched this on a 1080p LED tv and the colors and details are amazing, you feel like you are in the game/movie, the retro feel of the Fix-It Felix game to the intensity of the Hero's Duty game really capture what arcade gaming is about, the Sugar Rush game is the best with all the colors and details of the background and the supporting characters, the writers and animators were very clever with all the details and you can tell this movie is a labor of love for all to enjoy.Finally, the heart of the movie is not only in its graphics and video game cameos but the story, I think most people have felt like Ralph (John C. Reilly), misunderstood, unappreciated and unwanted in their lives, it is nice that he tries to improve his lot in life by reaching his goals and you can really feel for him when he sees Vanellope (played beautifully by Sarah Silverman) going through something similar in her game, they form a bond and it is hard not to smile as the story unfolds and you can laugh, cry and feel good about yourself and for the characters at the end of the movie. I highly recommend this movie for anybody who wants to enjoy a good movie and if you can, enjoy with some you love, you won't regret it.
summary: Finally a video game movie done right
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: 2012 a disappointing year for Disney animation.  Brave was just ok.  So is this one.You would have figured Disney would have made this enjoyable IF you are older or NOT into video games.  They did not.Unless you are a little kid or a video game fan you will not really care.Took long enough to get into the point nor important characters.Now, A HUGE DISLIKE OF THIS AS THEY RECENTLY DID WITH THE FIRST BLU RAY RELEASE TO THE 1953 CLASSIC "PETER PAN".  If/when you push pause instead of getting the film to pause you get five second until unnecessary stuff pops up on the screen.A few years ago Disney gave up on going good jobs on DVD releases & they were ONLY to blu rays.  THAT HAS STOPPEDThis is a four disc set, the discs are put in only two spots so if you want one at the bottom you have to pull two discs out.  NO art work on the discs anymore.  Cheap, cheap, cheap & so disappointing Disney.No special extras on this at all.So, the film is disappointing unless you are a kid or a video game fan, blu ray/DVD package also a disappointment.
summary: Film was disappointing to me-no big deal

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: There really is no downside to this movie. The characters are memorable, the animation is top notch and the message is just great. Summary: My daughter is 3 and cannot watch this movie enough; I am 42 and I watch it every time with a smile on my face.Every character in this movie will stick with you. There are no "ok" characters. Every one of them has been carefully crafted to appeal to an child AND an adult.The animation is great. It is the subtle things, like the cake splatter in the penthouse looking 8-bit, the way characters of certain vintages move and act. Classic. If you hung around an arcade between 1985 and 1995, you are going to experience some serious nostalgia.I do not want to spoil the end, but suffice it to say my entire family, including two of my friends, got misty eyed with admiration. Ralph is the man!
summary: Best animated film in a LONG time
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The Short: Wreck-It Ralph is a classic. From the slick animation, the great sense of humor, nostalgia inducing references and cameos, and the surprisingly adept and emotional story, Disney's Wreck-it Ralph is the best animated comedy since Tangled, and one of Disney's best animated films ever crafted.Street Fighter, Pac-Man, Q-bert; widely known and considered classic games. But a "new challenger has entered the ring" in the form of old school, Donkey Kong inspired retro arcade game, Wreck-it Ralph. Follow the misadventures of Wreck-it Ralph, voiced by John C. Reilly, as he attempts to become a hero by jumping though various video games. I don't want to spoil any of the plot, but it is incredibly well told and is quite surprising in the end. It has that classic Disney emotion, but with a most unique "video game-y" twist. In the end, Wreck-it Ralph teaches some great lessons, but it is also neither mundane nor juvenile, and that's why it's a winner.The cast here couldn't fit the characters better. John C. Reilly as the big guy Wreck-it Ralph, Sarah Silverman as the spirited and surprisingly funny Vanellope von Schweetz, Jane Lynch as the stoic and hilarious Sergeant Calhoun, and Jack McBrayer as the lovable and yet again laugh- out-loud Fix-it Felix Junior. The movie is absolutely hilarious; the performances from all of the actors fit their roles perfectly and couldn't be funnier. They couldn't have picked a better voice cast, honestly to goodness.The animation continues the high pedigree that Disney has become famous for. Its bright and lively action is wonderful to watch, and combined with great facial animations make for a great and emotional experience. But the winner here is the way that they have adapted the old- school style of video game animation into the film itself. You'll know what I mean when you see the movie. It makes for a truly unique, one of a kind experience! Sony's 4K presentation is crisp and vibrant.The thing to understand though is that with its focus on video game cameos and references, don't worry! You don't have to have any knowledge of video games to understand or enjoy Wreck-it Ralph. The story and main characters are all part of the film's story and world. Rather than using the references as a crutch, they're used more as a springboard into new and unexplored fictional worlds.Granted, gamers of all ages are going to love the care and attention taken when putting in the huge amount of references, cameos, and little bits of easter eggs spritzed and scattered throughout Wreck-it Ralph, making for a truly nostalgic inducing experience.And those classic Disney trademarks, from great characters to a well told story, are all here and are much more than side attractions. The twist is great, the concepts are fresh, and the level of imagination at work revives my faith in the animated genre. There's still plenty left in this old dog after all.And so I have to end this review by asking, "Are you tired of the same old washed up animated feature film? Feel like you're just too old for childish animated movies?" Wreck-it Ralph is the perfect cure. And it's meant for that group of movie goers looking for something more than just another animated money pit. It's laugh out loud funny, exciting and fresh, incredibly inventive and gleefully unique at every turn.It's a classic no doubt, and Wreck-it Ralph will be one of those movies on my "favorites" shelf for decades to come. The true triumph? Wreck-it Ralph feels like that classic game that has been a part of my childhood ever since I can remember; the type of classic where you throw hundreds of quarters away and you honestly just don't care, because it is just that good.5/5 - Perfection; Stop reading and watch right now
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Year after year, the expectation is that Pixar will release the best animated film, with second fiddle going to either Disney or Dreamworks.  The two possible exceptions to this trend have been Dreamworks' "How to Train Your Dragon" and Disney's "Tangled".  Now we have another alternative, "Wreck-It Ralph", Disney's big fall release of 2012.  Following in the transformation of Disney films from fairy tale musical to more focused on action and comedy, this movie contains elements from many of the other successful animated films of the past 20 - 30 years.  First, its numerous references to video games both overt and sly hearken back to the first Shrek, and to a smaller extend, the Toy Story films, in how they feature associations to culturally known icons.  The film's ensemble cast, and their relationships on stage also bear striking semblance to prior animated hits, most noticeably Monster's Inc.  Sully corresponds to Wreck-It Ralph.  Mike Wazowski becomes Fix-It Felix, and Boo is now Venellope.  The key difference is that the relationship between Sully and Wazowski in Monster's Inc is flipped 180 degrees in Wreck-It Ralph.  For me, the best part of the movie was the soundtrack; mixing elements of hip-hop, techno, disco and the traditional video game background music, it was a key part of the film's emotional punch.  As for this blu-ray / DVD package, it contains the film, the short clip that came before the movie in the theaters, and some additional features.  Like Disney's other films, the extra/deleted scenes are just sketches with voice-overs.  All in all, a great film and my vote for the best animated film of 2012.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: "Wreck-It Ralph" is a computer-animated family-action film. The story takes the imaginative direction of life for video game characters during their downtime with Wreck-It Ralph the lead protagonist.Ralph (John C. Reilly) doesn't like his bad guy role and wants to find more meaning by exploring beyond his game, and uses the shared electrical power board as a junction to other games.It is his voyage of discovery which introduces him to Vanellope von Schweetz (Sarah Silverman) and both face different predicaments in their respective games. Their coming together is the primary feature of the narrative and as a team they help not only themselves but game characters that have become redundant.For any viewer who played a video game in the 1980s/90s there are many familiar characters who have come on hard times and like Ralph they feel a bit disenfranchised, but he and Vanellope help them rediscover themselves, which creates some interesting game scenarios and relationships as the background stories of characters across many games provides much humour, as does their interaction because they have notably different game roles.John C. Reilly has the perfect deep, gravelly voice for smash hands Ralph and Sarah Silverman gives Vanellope a playful and energetic tone, which provides an enjoyable contrast between the two characters.It is a fun movie which is original and takes video games to a new level.Nicholas R.W. Henning - Australian Author
summary: Video game characters search for fulfillment

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: It's all fun and games at Litwak's Fun Center, until someone gets hurt. While this cliche'd line seems to reflect the simple plot in most movies (while the moral outcome does, too), the setting makes Wreck-it Ralph a wonderful, refreshing, and unique pleasure. Inside a family arcade, all the game characters (both old and new) are real, and travel among the other games when the doors have locked. Ralph, from Fix-it Felix Jr., desperately wished to be a good guy, and be rewarded, so he sets off in search of a medal. By doing this, he sets off a chain of events that puts multiple games at risk, and unveils a hidden threat.Disney has made this film equally accessible by both parents and children, and I find that wondrous. At times, Vanellope sounded quite mature, and at others, just like a tod. Soon, kids will squeal in excitement when they find a Fix-it Felix Jr. game, along with other last-gen arcade delights. In this way, the film has rendered itself timeless, if only in that small way. Although it doesn't feature many of the games themselves, you are able to see many characters, including retired ones.Being inside a game world gave the artists a great deal of freedom, but they didn't waste it. At every new turn, another extremely creative point would grab your attention, and I'm sure I missed many (which would enhance a second viewing). Another big enhancement is the 3D atmosphere. I doubted I would ever say this, but I urge you to see this in 3D, or turn around and go home. Because of all the pixel-related artwork, and 3D modeling, it is natural to have such a dimension added on. It's the perfect film to have it for!Now, for all the extra material surrounding the movie. Similar to Pixar, Disney has included an animated short right before, called "The Paperman". It doesn't feature any voice acting, but it's hilarious, and very well-made. I am sure you'll enjoy it. Second, the end credits are worth watching through, but not because there's an extra scene (there isn't one). It's only worth it for the visuals during the credits themselves, in 3D.In conclusion, Wreck-it Ralph is family-safe, and highly enjoyable. See it in 3D as soon as you can!

reviewText: Watching this movie made me fill-up with nostalgia and tears, as characters of my youth were vividly brought to life. The most surprising part, to me, was the consistency of each character with the graphics-game-play with the console and year of publication of each game. From PacMan to King Koopa, I was transported to my early days and enjoyed very much seeing these guys come to life.Puns, jokes, references, this movie has a real punch-in-the-face sense of humor, making you laugh out loud.The in-depth message of the movie is also cleverly interwoven. Ralph desperately seeks to find "himself" and try to become what he thinks he must become to feel like he matters. Jealous of Fix it Felix Jr., Ralph tries to find a medal so he may receive the common praise from the neighbors. The journey Ralph goes through is called going "Turbo", when a character invades another game and literally crashes it. Ralph's journey teaches him that the real medal is the one you find within, by understanding who you are and the importance of accepting yourself as such:"There is no one else I'd rather be than me."Absolutely amazing.

reviewText: Ralph just wants to fit in, is that so much to ask.  Most movies that center around games don't have the heart or emotional depth of this movie. As an everyday antagonist in Fix-it-Felix, he wants the rest of the characters in his game to accept him.  When he gets rejected he sets off on a quest making friends, learning just how important his place in his world really is, and ends up revealing his heart of gold.  Ralph brings tearful smile to my face every time we watch it.

reviewText: First, I want to say that  the "Paperman" short and featured title are just an irresistible package.  While I was able to view the short uninterrupted and in its entirety, the same can not be said of "Wreck-It Ralph".  I've rented the DVD twice before purchase, both from a Red Box and it keeps skipping over the same parts throughout the movie.  At first, I blamed the condition of those public rental disc but when I received the brand new DVD from Disney, it skips at the same spots as well.I am sick and tired of companies like Disney and Sony encoding their discs with extra measure stuff (and/or using cheap quality products).  Why use DRM on stuff when it's only punishing the consumers who actually buy the products.  Disney's FastPlay feature is a misnomered and deceptive option to fool you into watching the marketing stuff before getting to the main menu.Granted it seems to be only happening on my computer, which I now use to watch all my movies, but my computer is only two years old and was installed with quality components.  Also, this doesn't happen to the majority of my other DVD's that I own or have rented, so why should it only happen for certain products from certain companies?I'm debating going through the hassle of returning this product since I used the Super Savings option for free shipping, which would obviously be charged for a return.  In short, I like the animated short and movie, but hate the disc features.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The movie is fun, fast, and full of video game culture references, but everyone knows that. Under the candy-coated veneer is an emotional story about self-worth, friendship, and empathy. The characters are loveable, the animation is excellent, and the J-pop and dubstep soundtrack is actually enjoyable and fun. While it is rated PG, I didn't find it scary or inappropriate, but you should probably preview it before showing it to any really little ones just in case your tastes differ. My family loves it, it's our kid movie du jour.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This film in a wonderful way to spend an evening and while children may not appreciate the nuances the adult writers inserted into this film.Sarah SIlverman as the character voice of Princess Venelope - a main character - was annoying because she doesn't sound like a child, she sounds like Silverman trying to sound childish. It is probably the only sticking point in an otherwise wonderful movie filled with visual displays that deliberatly shift to show the many progressive technology steps computer games have gone through over time.I went away from this film with a smile on my face which shows that even an adult can enjoy this movie without having to bring the kids.
summary: Wonderful way to spend an evening

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: EDIT: Rewrite to emphasize this is my opinion and take on this animate film. Not some empirical fact.I had high expectations about this film. It was well received by critics and all the hoopla in the media. However, I left the theater rather disappointed.I said it before and will say again: in a figurative sense, there's nothing original or innovative about this film. Yes, in a literal sense it's a new setting, theme and characters, but in the truer sense it's just nothing there that jumps as something fresh. Same old anthropomorphism, same old predictable plot and narrative.As for the characters, I will quote myself, if I may, from the comments below:"Woody and the cast of Toy Story are not only the pioneers but they are the industry standard. They are amazingly easy to empathize with, and there's also a human aspect to the movie in the form of a growing Andy. In Toy Story 3, this [dynamic] reached a climax that had me (a guy in his 30s) openly and abundantly crying in the theater. Lightning McQueen & Co. are also very relatable and there's something to be said about the beautiful imagery and fantastic voice acting of Luke Wilson. However, Cars 2 fell off a cliff. The plot was all over the place, the characters became detached and artificial and plastered with a tried-and-true happy ending. Wreck-It Ralph simply did not speak to me. I didn't find the characters particularly relatable, humor was [completely] absent and I just did not find any particular hook to any of the characters."Also, I'd like to emphasize that this film is not unwatchable and if you have kids who are into video games I'm sure they'll get a kick out of it, but as an adult with hefty expectations, this film simply didn't deliver.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The kids love it... From my 3 year old to my 11 year old...they just want to watch it over and over again. Worth owning if you have kids...or a kid at heart!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: *Might have Spoilers*Wreck it Ralph was everything a great Disney movie, and good video game movie should be.  A wonderful story, engaging and believable characters, and wonderful visuals.  There is something for everyone in this film, especially people like me who grew up playing video games since the 80's.Wreck it Ralph centers around Ralph, resident bad guy for the arcade game Fix it Felix.  Day in and day out Ralph carries on his duties of wrecking one lone building, only to be defeated by Felix and the residents all the time.  Getting tired of always being labeled and treated like a "bad guy," Ralph starts game jumping in hopes of becoming a hero and earning the respect and love Felix receives.Later on, he meets Vanellope van Schweetz in the game Sugar Rush.  Vanellope is a character with her own things to prove.  As a glitch in her respective game, her goal is to show characters in her game that she can race just as good as they can; despite her problem.Throughout the movie, the question lies on what makes a person; especially what makes a person a "good" guy, or a "bad" guy.  It also show what defines a hero, and that medals and labels are not what makes a true hero to somebody.What was also great about this film is Disney really took the time and research to appeal to gamers such as myself.  Anyone who has played console and arcade games since the 1980's will go giddy with excitement with all the references Disney managed to stuff into the film.  From Bowser, Zangief, and M. Bison at the Bad Anon meeting to the "Aerith Lives" FVII reference in graffiti on one of the walls at the game station; there is something for everyone.Wreck it Ralph is a wonderful movie for kids and adults and it's on my top ten Disney movie list.  I feel Disney really made a stupendous effort and it's one of the best movies they made in the past 20 years.
summary: Greatest Video Game Movie of all Time
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Walt Disney ventures into the world of videogames in the fun-filled animated family feature Wreck-It Ralph. Wreck-It Ralph (John C. Reilly) is a misunderstood arcade game villain who longs to be beloved like his kind-hearted nemesis Fix-It Felix (Jack McBrayer), but nobody seems to like a Bad Guy. In order to order to prove himself a real hero, he ventures into the new first-person shooter game Hero's Duty to win a shiny medal, but accidentally unleashes a terrible evil that threatens the entire arcade. Wreck-It Ralph is one of the most entertaining animated films in recent years. It features a creative storyline filled with plenty of heart, emotion and humor, colorful CG animation and memorable characters. The animated movie is also homage to the videogame industry, featuring numerous video game references and iconic characters. Wreck-It Ralph also includes the voice talents of Sarah Silverman, Jane Lynch, Alan Tudyk, Mindy Kaling, Joe Lo Truglio, Dennis Haysbert and Ed O'Neill.Disney's Blu-Ray release of Wreck-It Ralph is well recommended addition to your Blu-Ray collection. The animated feature is presented in 2.39:1 widescreen format. The HD transfer is truly excellent with fine crystal clarity and rich dazzling colors. The 7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio track is certainly first-rate. The key extra in this Blu-Ray release is the Academy-Award-winning animated short Paperman. Other supplemental features include the 17-minute featurette Bit by Bit: Creating the Worlds of Wreck-It Ralph, 14 minutes of deleted and alternate scenes, Disney Intermission hosted by Chris Hardwick and sneak peeks of other Disney titles. Overall, Wreck-It Ralph scores a "B+".
Title: Wreck It Ralph
