Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This will be my 300th review on Amazon, and I saved it for something truly special, and that something special is Wreck-It Ralph. It is my new favorite movie, taking the crown from my last favorite movie, which reigned from 1995 until 2013. I was so awestruck by this movie that after we rented it, we bought the HD digital version from Amazon Instant Video before it was available on disc, and watched it over and over again, and I have now bought the movie on blu-ray as well (Disney is getting their money out of me) so I can watch it without having to wait for things to buffer :)This movie resonated with me in ways that I haven't experienced in a long, long time. Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING "clicked" perfectly for me with this movie. I realize that just because I love a movie, doesn't mean everyone else will, but I will try to explain below my reasons why I love it, in the hopes that people who may not have wanted to give this movie a chance, will do so.First, the sound is just perfect. If you played video games in the 1980s, you will immediately recognize the sounds they use in the movie, and that will raise the nostalgia level for you. They also integrate those same types of sounds into the music, making the whole movie "feel" like a video game.Second, the themes in the movie of the misunderstood "bad guy" and the underdog situations are very compelling to me. [Minor spoiler] And being the father of an adopted daughter, I empathized strongly with Ralph adopting Vanellope and looking after her, and putting her goals and needs above his. I think anyone who has cared for a child will resonate with that theme.[/END: Minor spoiler]Third, the voice acting is superb. I love, LOVE Sarah Silverman, and having her voice Vanellope was just beyond genius. She has one of those voices that I would recognize anywhere, like James Earl Jones -- it is instantly recognizable. Even the supporting cast got great voice actors that fit their characters well. I especially loved Alan Tudyk's take on King Candy as a modified Mad Hatter-type character (he has stated himself that he based his character's performance on the Ed Wynn's Mad Hatter from Alice in Wonderland).Fourth, I loved Calhoun (the tough female soldier). I love that she is a nail-biting no-nonsense soldier who also feels vulnerable on the inside when someone calls her a "dynamite gal." Her side story with Felix is very believable and very touching at times.Fifth, I loved the idea of "Bad Anon" as a support group for "bad guys" in games, and seeing old favorites from Mortal Kombat, Mario, and even Pac-Man sitting around and sharing about how they "may be bad guys, but, that doesn't make them ... bad ... guys..." :)Sixth, I really can't get enough of the "Toy Story" idea of what's-going-on-when-we're-not-looking? They said so themselves in the special features of the blu-ray that they were exploring that trope with this movie, and I am more than OK with that. I find it fascinating to think of video game characters living out separate lives from their games once the humans go away ... and they've barely scratched the surface of gaming! There are MMORPGs, console games, handheld games, phone games, Flash games, and more to still explore. I can see all kinds of possibilities for a sequel.Finally, I loved the ending.[Moderate Spoiler Warning]....There are certain kinds of human actions that I think most people will say captivate their attention, send shivers running up and down their spine, and invoke a certain kind of awe -- and I would say that self sacrifice for the greater good (a'la Spock) or for a loved one, tend to rank the highest in our admiration.  The moment where Ralph makes the tough decision and realizes what the greater importance is, and what kind of honor and medals truly count, and then acts on it, is a fantastic one. The music of the moment is perfect, and the build-up to the moment is perfect, and the resolution to the action is perfect. (See, I didn't spoil it too badly ^_-)[/END: Moderate Spoiler Warning]In my opinion, Disney hit it out of the ballpark with this one. I was mildly surprised to see that Disney was behind the movie when it came out, and impressed. They have certainly come a long way from Home on the Range (widely considered to be not just one of the worst Disney movies of all time, but one of the worst animated movies of all time).I own this movie, and I love it. It is a rare gem. It is heartwarming, family-friendly comedy/action/adventure with a video game twist. There is no swearing (although there is a bit of juvenile bathroom humor I could have done without), there is no serious violence (the only things that get truly hurt or killed in the movie are monster bugs, and Disney-villains, and they just vaporize when they die), and there are no serious dark elements to the movie. It is a movie you can put on when you want to feel better about the world, and it is my new favorite movie.5 stars.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Wreck it Ralph(released Oct/12)stars the voice talents of,among others,John C. Reilly as Wreck-It Ralph,Sarah Silverman as Vanellope von Schweetz,Jack McBrayer as Fix-It Felix, Jr.,Jane Lynch as Sergeant Tamora Jean Calhoun and Alan Tudyk as King Candy.This is a nicely done effort by the Disney Studios which I found generally to be an enchanting and entertaining opus.Kids from the 80s,now grown ups with kids themselves,will especially relate to the old style video arcade games that are revisited on screen.The story introduces us to a video arcade and one game in particular,Fix it Felix.The nemesis of the game is Wreck it Ralph.He sits high atop an apartment building and tries to wreck it.The hero Felix's schtick is to undo all the damage Ralph does.Something very similar to Donkey Kong.We soon go inside the game to see what happens after the arcade shuts down.Ralph's "home" is the nearby garbage dump,while Felix lives in the apartment building surrounded by many friends.The schism that exists causes Ralph to attend a "bad-anon" meeting to talk out his frustrations with other"baddies".The motto of the group is to take things"one game at a time".When Ralph returns home that night a party is in progress at the apartment building.It seems Felix and his friends are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the game.Ralph weasels himself an invite,but after an argument ensues with some tenants he storms out.After every game Felix gets a medal for winning.Ralph thinks that if he got one his street cred would rise considerably.Ralph leaves the game and goes to game central.Along the way he bumps into a soldier from Hero's Duty who has PTSD big time.After learning that one gets a medal for winning in the game,he"borrows" the soldiers suit and joins the game.Ralph soon finds out it is harder than it looks,and after bumbling through his first play the group all leave to the start line again.Ralph learns the medal he seeks is in a tall tower.Ralph climbs the tower and gets himself the medal.However on his way out he steps on an egg which spawns a bug,which immediately clings to his face.This causes Ralph to fall into a spacecraft which flies away and eventually crash lands in a game called Sugar Rush.The female leader of the Hero's Rush game and Felix,who has shown up looking for Ralph,also follow him.In Sugar Rush Ralph's medal has ended up on the branch of a candy cane tree.On his climb up he meets a "glitch".When she/the glitch realizes what he's after she steals it away from him and runs off.She uses Ralph's medal to enter herself in the upcoming kart race.But the King is dead set against her racing and he tries everything to stop her.Meanwhile Ralph catches up to glitch and they come to terms with each other.In return for Ralph helping her enter and win the race,she will give Ralph his medal back.The two create a candy go kart and practice her driving.Just before the two are about the leave for the race,glitch goes back to get something for Ralph.At this moment the King shows up and gives Ralph his medal back.He also asks Ralph to stop glitch from racing.His reasoning is if she won,the entire game itself would likely be shut down when human players saw her glitching out constantly.When glitch returns he wrecks the kart and returns home,leaving poor glitch in tears.Back home practically everyone has gone,as Ralph's disappearance has left the game unplayable.As Ralph stares at the out of order sign,he throws his medal at the playing screen which has the effect of partially dropping the sign on the outside.At that moment Ralph sees a picture of glitch on the side of her game across the arcade.Funny that a glitch should be shown prominently on a game she shouldn't be in.Ralph returns to Sugar Rush to learn that the King deliberately made her a glitch,tearing her memory from the system code,long ago.Ralph finds glitch locked up in a "fungeon" and releases her,after some apologies.The race begins and even though she starts late,glitch hits the road running.The race never quite finishes as the bug that accompanied Ralph into Sugar Rush has now grown and spawned an army of them.Felix and the commander of Hero's Duty finally catch up with Ralph and assist him in fending off the bug attack.It is during this time we learn the King is also the hero from an old game called Turbo Time,who took over and killed off a similar game way back when,and has now ruled this one for years.The two battle,the King goes down along with the army of bugs, and Ralph gets to finally push glitch over the finish line.This reboots the game and glitches former role of the princess of the game is reinstated.Ralph returns home a happier more loved bad guy and glitch and he remain best friends forever.Many who watch this and are familiar with the old arcade games,will meet a myriad of old friends here like Sonic the Hedge Hog,Cubert,Bowser(from Mario),Pacman and more.It is obvious what demographic the producers of this film were after.It also works wonderfully with children as most of the characters here are thoroughly benign in behaviour and looks.That is why I say in the title that it is like Reboot,but without that animation's edge to it.The only fault I find with animation such as this is in the writing.The stories tend to get a little too complicated,and as the film winds down there are alot of loose ends to tie up,and some extras added on.Such as the side plot of the King and his past.If they had left it with just the King trying to marginalize glitch,that would have been sufficient.But instead they made the King into the guy from Turbo Time.All this while Felix and company are fighting bugs and Ralph is fighting for his life.I did think it was a neat touch that the King's affectation was along the lines of old comedian Ed Wynn.In fact kudos to all who voiced the film.Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 2:35:1.The only extra is the 10 minute animated short The Paperman,seen in theatres along with this film.All in all an enjoyable animated romp back to the heady days of arcade games of the 80s.Fix it Felix bears more than a striking resemblance to the Donkey Kong of old.Kids from the 80s,now grown up,will relate to the subject matter easily,and their children will love the film for its adventuresome theme and larger than life characters.Recommended.

reviewText: Its amazing the difference one person can make, In this case, John Lassiter's move across from Pixar to Disney has spelled the end of Pixar's extraordinary creative run and a mini revival at Disney. There have now been three Disney movies under his guidance, Tangled, Wreck-It Ralph and Frozen, and they are all pretty impressive to watch but this is the best. The problem with the other two are that they are deeply sexist - man-hating. Tangled is simply appalling in the scenes of violence enacted against the mail lead, Repunzel's repeated bashing him over the head with a frying pan, knocking him unconscious every time, would kill an ordinary person, and sends a clear message to young girls: its never ok for people to hit females, but you girls can feel free to enact physical violence on men. Frozen is worse again: the man-hating is so deeply, and unnecessarily, in its core that they seem to be losing some editorial balance.And here in the middle of these two films, which could have been completely wonderful but aren't, is the more modest but beautifully balanced Wreck-It Ralph, with very strong and lovely male and female leads, and a gentle and generous moral journey. It's not one of the very great Disney movies but a fine addition to the collection.It will certainly survive a a classic, and it won't date like the other two. It is enjoyable for children of both sexes, and Ralph's core concerns as an outsider make the film appealing to adults, without the gratuitous sarcasm of Shreck and its genre.There are problems with it: some say it should not have settled in the world of Sugar Rush, but Sugar Rush is a very interesting place to be. If I had a complaint about the film it would be that the actual game of Fix-It Felix isn't worked through sufficiently, so it isn't immediately obvious why anybody would want to play it. Others complain about the several references to The Wizard of Oz; I found them delightful. The world of Sugar Rush is obviously tilted towards an East Asian sensibility - the Hello Kitty kind of cutesy-pie worlds, but it is fun all the same.The best thing in the movie is the world of the aliens and traumatized military heroes,, and the uber-masculine female corporal who holds everything together. She's simply hilarious, and her budding respect for and then love for the hapless Fix-It Felix is one of the film's many joys. The script-writers worked hard to keep the movie entertaining throughout and perhaps the best moment is right near the end, when Felix is in jail and tries to break out with his magic hammer. It is such a delightful surprise, it reminds me of another comedy that never took one moment for granted, Back to the Future, and the scene where the Michael Fox character sees his mother's family in the fifties and his uncle as baby in a play pen, and utters the immortal line, "better get used to those bars, kid."
summary: The best of the recent batch of Disney hit movies
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I thought the movie itself was fantastic. I liked it both at the theater and recently at home. No complaints there, so I'll toss it a solid four stars while mirroring other praise in these reviews. But the one nitpicky thing I have about the disc itself is the five-second countdown when the movie is paused, after which it jumps into a bonus feature. After two times of restarting the entire film to get away from peppy people talking about stuff at a seemingly louder volume than I was watching the actual feature at, I was finally able to wrestle my PS3 remote into revealing the magic "go" button, so at least that trial is over.But seriously? For the most part, I want pause to pause and do nothing else. Battletoads raised the bar by giving you a catchy NES percussion tune, but that's about as much as I can take. And as far as I know, there's no way to disable this Blu-Ray's feature, so briefly stopping the film is going to be a "one-two" pause-mute affair while you step out of the room for popcorn or a drink.Bonus features also include the "Paperman" short. I hope that style of animation sees feature-length someday.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This was a clever film with a cute story about a game "villian" in a Donkey Kong-style game wanting for something more, set in a TRON-style world on networked arcade games.  The homage to retro games was well done, although the retro characters seem to be more primarily established, then left, in the earlier part of the film, as the later half dwells more in the candy world.  Honestly I would have liked to see more of the retro characters, but that's just me, having grown up in the '80s arcade era.  Ralph is a clever villain-turned-hero, but his glitch friend really grows old really fast (her voice sounds like an adult trying hard to sound like a child, and it just gets excruciating after awhile, to the point you want to skip ahead past her scenes.)It's an all-ages film for the most part, but there are some scary sequences, namely the final character which, to be honest, I thought was just disturbing and a little too creepy for a kids film.

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This movie is not enjoyable for adults.  The choice to have most of the movie take place in a land that looks like Hello Kitty was splashed across a candy store catering to 5 year old girls was a huge mistake.  That choice ruined what from a technical standpoint must be seen as excellent graphics. The plot was sappy and thin, and I couldn't wait for this to be over.  I know the world is dominated by 5 year olds, but throughout history starting with Warner Brothers' Bugs Bunny, through to Pixar, it's been proven that one doesn't have to pander to make a film that is appealing to children.  This is a weak effort.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The storyline was deep and intelligent enough for adults to appreciate it, but not so much so that it was above a small child's head. The retro throwbacks-- adorable. And Fix it Felix and Vanelope and Calhoun were very much just Jack McBrayer and Sarah Silverman and Jane Lynch in animated form-- the personality shone completely through all three.And, of course, how could you not love Ralph, the anti-hero of the story?  The old video game jokes were cute, but the fact that the "bad guys" went to "Bad anon" like alcoholic anonymous? That was hilarious. (Though, when he was clutching his cookie medal and saying the creedo? I CRIED...)This hearkens back to the old Rankin Bass in that Misfits have a place too, but, it's more than that. It's about yes, everyone has their place, but YOU decide who YOU are. It was a beautiful movie and message. Loved it, loved it, and my kids have watched it eight times since getting it last Sunday (it's Friday)!I think the part that choked me up the most was when he was talking about how if that one little girl loved him, he couldn't be SUCH a bad guy... and truly, Ralph WAS a hero. Cannot recommend this enough.
summary: This movie was more than cute and fun... it was brilliant!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: LOVE this movie. It's funny and cute with a heart. But it's clever twists and turns that make it special. I like these combo packs. Not only do they cover every format they give you a digital copy you can watch virtually anywhere you have internet access.

Again it is more like an amusement ride than a movie. Not for you if you are expecting some kind of  plot. It is just pure mindless fun.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Wow, I seriously don't give out that many 5 stars reviews, but this one I had no problem what so ever. I can't believe it myself. It was just that super, amazing, great Disney film that I haven't seen for a long while.Why is this movie so good? Disney somehow managed to make a movie that works for both little kids and kept the adults still loving it too. Yes, this movie is still gears towards the little kids more, but that's okay, because most likely you're watching this with a little kid(s) anyways.Can a "bad guy" be really a "good guy"? For once in his life? Forever...maybe? Let see, yes he can! Wreck-IT-Ralph is about Ralph who is a video game bad guy and he was programmed to be a bad guy and he loves it! But, after awhile of doing bad things, he starts to feel he wants to be more than just the bad guy in his game and maybe be a good guy for once? Maybe even get a shinny medal on the way.You would think a zebra can't change his strips, but nothing impossible and even more so in this movie. Ralph went through a roller coaster of events and he actually did get a medal in this new game called Hero's Duty. Maybe he didn't get the medal the way it was supposed to get it, but it's his and he earned it his way. lol You will find it very funny yourself, once you see him get it.However, in unfortunate of events happened right after Ralph gets his medal. The medal he just won, then is lost too. Now comes in Vanellope a glitch in this new game that Ralph is in called Sugar Land. Vanellope is a very funny and playful character. She is also a glitch in the game and wants to become a true racer. Ralph of course hates her because she lost Ralph's medal, but now they both need each other help. Ralph will get back his medal and Vanellope can become a true racer, if they work together. This was very funny to watch for kids and adults alike.What adults will find very funny is the video game jokes, if you were into video games back then of course. If you weren't then some of the references may fly by over yourself, but that's okay because there more to this movie than just jokes. This movie is also about friendship, wanting something so much that you do anything for, making tough choices in life, and finally self sacrificing one life to save someone else.I left out a lot of things, and it is just too much to put down. I also don't want to spolier it for you and want you to watch this movie. I recommend this movie to everyone!!!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This film surprised me tenfold when I first saw it in theaters. I went in expecting another boring Pixar wannabe, something with dumb jokes aimed towards immature kids alone and not really any storyline or character to identify with. But this one really knocked me off my feet! Wreck-It Ralph is a film set apart from other animations that I've seen in recent years. It is a fresh perspective that does not disappoint, with a lovable set of characters from all walks of life. The dialogue in this movie is not the typical fodder you find in children's movies these days. It is intelligent, witty, and keeps me engaged. This is one of those movies made "for kids," but we all know very well that adults were a huge portion of the target audience. There is something here for everyone. Two thumbs up!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Ok, even I loved this one; of course, I watch every movie my kids watch anyway, but this one was really good.  Very colorful, loved the move "Sugar Rush"; I could not get that song out my head.  The plot, the whole movie flows very well.

reviewText: so this review isn't about the movie, cuz it was awesome, but just solely about the this bluray set.there are 4 discs, 3d bluray, bluray, dvd and digital copy. but there are only two holders, so each holder holds two discs. so basically its one disc on top of another on one side and another disc on top of another disc on the other side of the bluray case.so if i were you guys, i'd put the dvd discs in first, than the blurays on top of them so they aren't damaged. blurays are harder to scratch so they can be placed on top.the special features are pretty neat. you get all 4 video game commercials featuring wreck it ralph as it would of looked like if it really was a game back in the early 80's, sugar rush commercial, hero's duty commercial, and a commercial featuring felix juniors hammer which is pretty funny.theres a 16min featurette that talks about the film and how they came to make it. i would of hoped this featurette which was really fun to watch would of been longer and i'm sure it could of been longer. oh well.the deleted scenes/alternate scenes are really alternate scenes. if you see them, which they aren't even completed, they are a mix of pencil drawings with overlays and some very minor special affects to help tell the story that would of been. basically just simple storyboards that really had nothing to do with the final product. so that tells you how different the movie would of been or was in the beginning stages of making this film. they are pretty interesting to look at the route they thought of taking.obviously paperman short is here. a must see!and audio commentaries on the deleted/alternate scenes.so there you have it. i think i covered it all. enjoy!

reviewText: Whole family (including daddy) loved this movie. reviewText: I went into the store to ask about the Wreck-It Ralph litho that usually comes with pre-orders, and the sales associate informed me that Disney will no longer being doing lithos. They tested with Peter Pan to see if the lithos affected sales, half the stores offering them with the pre-orders and the other half not. They found that the lithos do not affect sales.In my original review, I stated how Peter Pan was a poor choice to test this idea on. Not everyone owns bluray, so if you already have it on DVD, why bother getting it again? And if you already had the litho, you were even more less likely to buy because again, why pay for something you already have?I said that they should only do it with the new releases, like Wreck-It Ralph  to really see how it affects sales.I also stated that since Disney would no longer be doing the lithos, my family would no longer be pre-ordering the movies. Instead we would just wait until it came out and buy it on Amazon where it's usually a couple bucks cheaper.I also suggested a writing campaign to try and convince Disney to bring back the lithos; they're all we have for interior decorating in our house.

reviewText: I am a huge video game fan, and the cameo appearances in the film really made the movie for me. Of course, the cameos all pretty much stop after the first 30 minutes of the movie and the actual plot takes hold.In this package you receive a Blu Ray disc with the standard Blu Ray, "2D" version, a second Blu Ray that includes the 3D version of the film and 2 DVDs. One is a DVD with the Disney Digital Copy for your iPod or other media player that is capable and also a standard definition DVD of the film. I spot checked the DVD, and it actually isn't bad. They did a pretty good job on that transfer as well. I proceeded to give the DVD to my brother so that my nephew has another Disney movie he can watch.I do not have a 3D capable TV. Yet. All of my comments are for the Blu Ray version. Once I get a 3D TV, I'll come back for another look as time permits.Video:Looks gorgeous.1080p AVC encoded. 2.39:1 ratio, that comes to full screen on a 16x9 TV.Audio:Sounds phenomenal. No faults detectable.7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio. I only have 5.1 capability on my system, but the soundtrack even at 5.1 doesn't disappoint. It just sounds darn good!Extras:About 30 minutes of extras that were mostly worth watching. Nothing amazing though, so if you skip the making of and the deleted scenes (done in storyboard format, not animation), there's not much left.Overall:An OK movie with a great Blu Ray release.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Okay, as you can see this review has been preceded by (as I post this) 580 other reviews! But let me guide you through Amazon's review system as well as give you my take on the DVD.Amazon has a general policy of grouping ALL the reviews of a film together and displaying them under all the formats. Reviews start when a film plays in theaters and then often goes to the Amazon Instant (streaming version).  So I often recommend - when posting my reviews - that you sort by "most recent" first and then look to see which version the reviewer is discussing.  (It's listed under their review.) If you are looking for special features, etc, that will help you. This is a review of the 4-disc 3D Bluray +Blu-ray+ DVD+Digital Copy, but it should guide you in your purchase, I hope.I'm afraid that I can't yet play 3-D discs so I can't help with that disc and the digital copies are now becoming standard as well the standard DVD - which you can play in your PC without a BD drive.The BD comes with four special features which total 42 minutes: There is 16- "Bit by Bit" where the Disney artists explain the five new "Worlds" (actually video games) and how each differs. Then come 5 "deleted" scenes (which are actually the animated storyboard of the scenes which play with - or without - commentary (15 minutes). There are four "fake" commercials for the new games that appear in the film (2  minutes total). And finally the Academy Award Winning animated short -"Paperman" (6 minutes). This last bonus has literally nothing to do with anything else on the DVD or BD (other than that it was from Disney studios) but I loved it and glad it's there.As for the film, I came of age before the video game revolution and I really don't frequent arcades so most of the clever nods to early games (okay, I KNOW Pac Man; who doesn't?) but I still enjoyed the humor and wonderful drawing. These characters seemed more real to me than the Toy Story ones from Pixar.  I would have liked a commentary track or comments from the voice over actors. The BD has the "intermission feature" which can be fun or annoying.  When you press "pause" "host" Chris Hardwick comes on and spends a 9 minute/11 "chapter" loop telling you where to find hidden game references in the film. The problem is that, when you press pause it's usually to answer the phone or leave the room momentarily and want quiet. What you get, however, is Chris chatting away (and not even facing the camera.)Since there are lots of opinions on the film, I'll let you read other views. I just hope this review was helpful in deciding if the 4 disc combo set is what you want.Steve Ramm"Anything Phonographic"
summary: Review of Bluray Combo Pack - 42-minutes of Bonuses but no full length commentary or interviews with voice actors.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: The newest Disney animated feature Wreck-It Ralph centers on a video game "bad guy," Ralph, who was programmed to wreck things but yearns to someday play the hero. In the previews, I admittedly thought this premise a cheesy one and a pale comparison to the technological existentialism of the TRON series.Fortunately, as with the past several Disney animated classics, I was wrong. Wreck-It Ralph is more about socially constructed labels and how we can overcome them. Only we can define ourselves, and it is never to late to change our actions to become a better person. I honestly found this to be one of the better and more meaningful messages from a Disney movie. It wasn't about Ralph being victimized or being outcast, as much as it was him proactively seeking a better way of life.In terms of its pure content, Wreck-It Ralph is a very funny and creative adventure through the world of video games. I am by no means a gamer, but I could still recognize and enjoy the different styles of games that Ralph explores. Some of the biggest laughs came from the character Sgt. Calhoun, the soldier protagonist of the fictional game Hero's Duty. As one character describes, "she has the most tragic backstory": her wedding was interrupted by an alien robot breaking into the church and killing her would-be husband. The entire audience, of mostly adults at my midnight premiere showing, was dying of laughter!While the movie runs a bit long, it is still a lot of fun and delivers a very powerful message. The last 15 minutes or so are emotionally powerful, as the threat of loss and sacrifice put the characters' lives at stake. Each of the characters transcend what they were programmed to do, to carry out actions and relationships that they know in their hearts are right. As the "bad guys" repeat at their focus group, "I am bad, and that's good, and that's not bad. There's no one I'd rather be than me."
summary: Excellent, emotionally mature new Disney film
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Wreck-It Ralph is not a movie about a video game, at least not an existing video game.  It is a movie in the fashion of Tron, a movie about the hidden world inside video games.Here is the premise:  Ralph is the heavy in a game called Fix-It Felix, a fictitious Donkey Kong-era arcade classic built into a coin-op cabinet that looks almost exactly like a Donkey Kong machine.Ralph, sensitively voiced by John C. Reily (probably best known as Will Ferrell's sidekick in Step Brothers and Talladega Nights), is tired of life as a bad guy.  As the movie begins, he confesses this  in a support group for game villains called Badanon.  Other members of the group include such video game luminaries as Kano (Mortal Kombat), Satan (Diablo), M Bison (Street Fighter II), Zangief (Street Fighter II), Doctor Ivo Robotnick (Sonic The Hedgehog), and Bowzer (Super Mario Bros).  The leading the discussion is Clyde, the orange ghost from Pac-Man.Classic game character cameos abound in Wreck-it Ralph.The place where video game characters go to socialize in this arcade is Tapper's, the bar from the Midway game Root Beer Tapper.  (For the sake of Disney audiences, the bar did not have the big Budweiser logo scene in the original version of the game, which was simply named, Tapper.  Good call, Disney.)Feeling particularly perplexed on the thirtieth anniversary of his game, Ralph would like to have people root for him for a change. Hoping to find a little solace, he decides to embark on a quest for a medal to prove he is not such an awful guy--a quest which will take him into dangerous new locales such as Hero's Duty, a game that combines the shooter-on-rails action of Time Crisis, with the art direction of Gears of War, and the monsters of Alien--an amalgam shooting game in which players enter a bleak world killing futuristic bugs.While in Hero's Duty, Ralph meets Calhoun, the meanest, toughest-talking she-soldier in the history of video games--brilliantly voiced by Jane Lynch of Glee fame.After his tour in Hero's Duty, Ralph visits the ultra sweet world of Sugar Rush, which is sort of Mario Kart set in Candyland.  There, he meets Vanellope, voiced brilliantly by Sarah Silverman, who, as a programming glitch, is shunned by the other characters in her game.He's a bad guy; she's a misfit, you can see the chemistry bonding a mile away... and no one handles these relationships as well as Disney.We'll leave the plot unspoiled from here.The obvious question that comes up is, "Is Wreck-It Ralph a movie for video game players.  The answer is, "Yes and No."  When it comes to cameos and references, the folks at Disney did NOT pull out all the stops.  There are lots and lots of game characters to spot--particularly in the arcade's electrical hub and along the wall of Tapper's; but the people who made this game did not go overboard.  They kept the story first and foremost, then let squeezed in game trivia whenever they cold.One of my favorite little trivia doffs was Mr. Litwak, the arcade owner.  A soft-spoken man dressed in an NFL Ref's shirt, he was clearly inspired by Walter Day, the world's most famous arcade owner and game record historian?  (Litwak--Waltir, I know, not a perfect anagram but close.)But you do not need to know about Walter Day or games like Road Blasters and Donkey Kong to fall in love with this perfectly executed, heart-warming, imaginative look into the secret life of video games.  Wreck-It Ralph is a fun, well-told, artistic story.
summary: Best Movie About Video Games So Far

reviewText: Great movie. Nice visuals and music. It's not just a good animated movie, it's a good movie on its own. Best video game movie ever made. Tons of cameos and scenes for us older folks/gamers that I loved. Two bad things. Mario (and maybe Luigi) is the most well known video game character in video game history but Nintendo didn't allow him (or Luigi) in the movie. Very disappointing Nintendo. The other is the packaging for the 3D combo pack. Why in the world would you package the discs to stacked on top of each other instead of normal individual flaps/pages inserts? This could damage them.

reviewText: Wreck-It Ralph is, like Monster's Inc, a fun family film.  The plot is simple, the jokes are funny, and the main characters entertaining.Then you peel back a layer, and it is a hilarious film for geeks and gamers who can happily play "spot the licensed games", argue over the Q-bert translations, and spend hours afterwards reminiscing about their own game experiences.Best of all, Disney made a film about video games that wasn't just "for boys".  The female characters are central to the plot, and not relegated to pink princess roles in castles!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: Wreak It Ralph is the next "Toy Story." It has diverse and delightful characters as it combines elements of "Tron," "Starship Troopers," and "Candyland." Ralph is a "bad guy" in a game. He wants to be a good guy and get a medal so he crosses over to another game and ends up in a third game where he meets the Vanellope whose voice is excellently portrayed by Sarah Silverman who made the film.The film has themes of being yourself, self sacrifice, and bullying. The language is sometimes saucy such as "gutter snipe" and "pussy willow." As an adult, I enjoyed this feature. It is one you can enjoy with your kids.

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Wow! This movie brought back memories of our arcade game days. It's absolutely hysterical and filled with nostalgia. We were able to point out various games to our kids and even broke out the old Atari and Nintendo to show the kids how "cool" the graphics were then. The storyline was highly entertaining -- as all Disney's are. Wreck-It Ralph is tired of always being the bad guy. He decides the only way to enjoy life is become a hero (aka win a medal). He jumps his game and finds himself in another where he accidentally unleashes a "bug" that can destroy a game. At first, he is focused only on himself and his needs until he realizes there's more to his world than just being a bad guy or being a hero. Sometimes what we need most is a friend.We laughed, we cried (from laughing so hard), we laughed some more. It was an awesome movie! We each have our favorite character and enjoy watching it over and over again. I believe this is one movie we will not soon tire of.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: My 17 year old daughter loves this movie. It is just an encouraging story about when you don't fit like everyone else or you want to change your life in some way. Good movie.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: A moving story that surrounds familiar feelings like being unrecognized or being an outcast.  Great for kids and adults alike.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I think this movie is the beginning of a new Disney golden age. The story is snappy, richer than I expected, and has good morals, the characters seem fresh and alive, and while its titular character is male and it seems like it might be a "boy's movie" (which is not a bad thing with so many princess movies coming out of Disney of late), it also has a sassy, strong willed (but caring and moral) female protagonist as well.I went to this movie thinking it'd be a bit of light fluff for a summer saturday afternoon, and was surprised to find myself crying at the sad parts and cheering at the ending. They did really good with this one.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Of course it was fun to see the old video game references (that would be lost on kids), but the story was pretty good as well.  The integration of all of the games and their characters was done very well.  I have to admit I did not expect the plot twist at all (I probably should have, but it eluded me).  I also liked that the requisite sad turn of events wasn't so bad that it made me tear up or squirm in my seat as they often do.  Overall a very fun movie that won't make kids cry.  The animation was excellent and the "sets" were extremely fun to watch as were the quirkiness of the characters.
summary: Simple fun with a lot of cool eye candy
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Likable characters.  Engaging story.  Great nostalgia factors for those of us who grew up in the '80s.  Celebrating the "least among us" storyline.And another movie with the moral that a "glitch", something that seemingly makes one different or "bad" or broken, isn't necessarily what it seems.  Maybe mostly because we can't trust the powers that be to have our best interests at heart but because they live out that adage "power corrupts, and absolute power corrupts absolutely".  It's a real message, and it's cynical but the kids won't pick up on this though is anyone else desiring a kids movie where the powers that be, foibled as they are, are still ultimately trustworthy?  Or is it just me?Rant aside every movie needs a good villain; I'm not sure that King Candy qualifies (voiced by a thick-tongued spit-spraying Alan Tudyk) but there are other villains here as well set against Vanellope including the programming of the giant bugs that will eat everything if left unchecked.  The most interesting, of course, is Wreck-It Ralph himself who is a villain in his own video game but he longs to be far more than his confining coding allows.  The film is both about his journey and Vanellope's, both of them fighting against the life they've been assigned to, and both needing to embrace that aspect about themselves that they loathe in order to embrace their full potential and break free of their restricting conscripts.The story is done nicely, tightly, but I am wondering here if we are feeding our kids too much of this particular line and not enough messages that brokenness means that something truly doesn't work in a useful way, that it is actually detrimental?  That is just as often if not more how our world, complicated and complex as it is, works.  Regardless, this movie is by far a delight with main characters that are allowed to inhabit some complexities (yes, even the "glass half-full" Fix-It Felix) and Ralph's visit to the Sugar Rush video game land will simply give you cavities and may lead to diabetes it's so chock-full of candy-coated delight!  It's the digital version of Candyland.So if you're looking for an intelligent, good-hearted kid's movie that can also be a platform to have some important discussions with your pre-teen kiddies then Wreck-It Ralph fits this bill quite nicely.  Video game fans from the original Nintendo generation should also have a blast.  (Make sure you check out the special feature that shows various nods to Disney and the history of video games all throughout the movie--cool!)
summary: Worthy addition to the Disney canon of original storys.  But, are the messages becoming all the same?
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: At first, I wasn't so sure what to think of this film. I thought Pixar, Dreamworks, or even Blue SKy Studios should have made this film. But that does not mean it was bad. No, it was better than I expected it. At first I thought it was going to be a journey movie where Ralph would meet and be accompanied by Vanellope Von Schweetz along the way. But actually...no. It turned out to be a story I hadn't seen before. Ralph helping Vanellope in a her crisis. Helping her dream come true while having to deal with the evil King Candy. ANd speaking of which, I found King Candy a very well developed villain. When I thought this was a journey movie, I wondered how King Candy would be the main villain? Would he want what Ralph was after? But when I saw that this was about helping Vanellope, I saw where it made sense. King Candy being silly throughout the movie and revealing his true identity and personality. Don't worry, I won't spoil it. I will admit though, much like "Toy Story 3", I thought the idea of humans unknowingly ending arcade game characters' lives was a bit frightening, especially King Candy's lie about Vanellope getting killed. That scene almost made me cry as well as Ralph destroying Vanellope's kart. But I am definetly glad Vanellope was cured in the end. I do wish this film got the Academey Award for Best Animated Feature. But hey, it did get the Annie Award for Best Animated Feature, so that has to count for something. Overall, I think "Wreck it Ralph" is a great CGI family film. What I think makes this stand out is Ralph and Vanellope's relationship. It is just heartwarming to watch.
summary: Should Have Been A Pixar film
Title: Wreck It Ralph

Classic and so cute!

reviewText: If you grew up playing games than you will really appreciate this movie. There's tons of throwbacks to older games and it's amazing how many iconic gaming characters Disney was able to use in the movie. Wreck-It-Ralph is one of the more unique animated movies I've seen thus far and it is definitely worth a purchase. You'll be able to watch it multiple times and still enjoy it which is really the only reason to ever buy a movie.Younger people may not get some of the references in this movie since a lot of it is from pretty old games and the same goes for people that don't play games at all. You won't appreciate Wreck-It-Ralph nearly as much if you don't know who most of the characters are. Seeing all the iconic gaming characters from the dawn of gaming is really what makes this movie so great. While watching the movie I began thinking about when I was younger and played most of those games. I've never seen a movie that made me remember so much from my childhood that I had forgotten over the years. It's a trip to say the least!Wreck-It-Ralph is one of the best films of the year in my opinion and I think everyone should see it at least once!
summary: Great Nostalgia For Us Older Gamer's!!!

reviewText: Have you ever felt like you were stuck in a role you never wanted to play? Constantly subjected to scorn and ridicule simply for performing the only task available to you? What if you could change that?Fix-it Felix Jr. has been a popular game in Litvak's for years. The hero and titular character, Felix (voiced by Jack McBrayer) has a magic hammer that can repair any damage done by the game's villain, Ralph. When the game is over, Felix is given a medal while Ralph (voiced by John C. Reilly) is tossed off the roof by the tenants of the building he failed to destroy. When the arcade closes and the game is turned off, Ralph returns to his home atop a garbage heap in the nearby dump. For recreation, he visits Tapper's, a vintage game that assigns the player the role of a bartender. Also, upon our introduction to the story, Ralph makes his first visit to a support group for video game villains. Among the villains in attendance at Bad-Anon, we see M. Bison and Zangief from Street Fighter (voiced by Gerald C. Rivers and director Rich Moore respectively), a ghost from Pac-Man (voiced by Kevin Deters), and a zombie (Raymond Persi). During that meeting, he announces he no longer wants to be a bad guy. With the 30th anniversary of Fix-it Felix Jr., the tenants throw a party and "forget" to invite Ralph. Ralph crashes the party, in every sense of the word, and leaves soon after. Before he's left, he vows to return with a medal, something denied him by Felix and the tenants of the building he destroys. He seizes the opportunity to travel to a new game, a first-person shooter game called Hero's Duty, when a character from that game passes out in the bathroom. While at the center of Hero's Duty, Ralph is overwhelmed by the violence in modern games and refuses to heed the orders of his superior, Sergeant Calhoun (voiced by Jane Lynch). Once the arcade closes and the game ends, Ralph decides to forego the usual hurdles of Hero's Duty and steal the medal typically awarded to the winner. After stealing the medal and, unwittingly, bringing a menacing enemy insect known as a Cy-bug with him, Ralph heads to the kart-racing game Sugar Rush. It's there that he encounters the perpetually glitchy and terminally annoying Vanellope von Schweetz (voiced by Sarah Silverman). Despite the initial friction, Ralph and Vanellope (Silverman) bond over their shared status as outcasts.There is, of course, more to the story including Felix's pursuit of Ralph into the various other games and his budding romance with the no-nonsense Sergeant Calhoun, the true origin of Silverman's character, and an eventual revolt in the world of Sugar Rush. All of it, and I do mean all of it, had me riveted. I will say that, as a fan of old-style video games, I would've preferred seeing the character of Ralph travel to more than just the two different games besides his. Regardless of my criticisms, Wreck-It Ralph is hilariously entertaining and fun for viewers of all ages. Check it out.

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Disney's new animation film "Wreck-It Ralph" follows the story of Ralph, a "villain" of an arcade game "Fix-It Felix, Jr." But Ralph is only playing the role of a villain. What he really wants to be is a hero.To win a hero's medal, Ralph leaves the world of an 8-bit game machine where he has been "working" for thirty years. After causing havoc in a first-person shooting game world (where he learns that a modern game is very "violent"), Ralph meets Vanellope, a cute little girl who is a character of a racing game "Sugar Rush."The film's premise looks simple at first, but as the story unfolds, the film has much more to offer, with a handful of clever twists and turns, as well as rich colors and detailed movements of game characters. The story of Ralph and Vanellope is sweet, reflecting the film's theme of friendship and self-discovery, but not too sweet, with credible character interactions.The old-fashioned games at arcade would make some adult viewers feel nostalgic, but the film does not rely on the idea to entertain us. There are also so many references to video games (a certain character is now "out of work"), but it is interesting and likable characters that move the plot forward. "Wreck-It Ralph" is a great example of Disney at its best. It is hugely enjoyable.

reviewText: The Disney Animated Classic, the most coveted of labels for an Animated feature film. The Hall of Fame consists of names like Pinocchio, Cinderella & The Little Mermaid. After a few years of rises and falls Disney brings us a new kind of classic film. One that focus more on originality as opposed to story book. With a years behind since Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs there a whole new generation of source material to shape a Disney film on and in its' 52nd Animated Feature Disney tackles the world of Video Games with 'Wreck-It Ralph'.This movie is just fantastic filled with amazing visuals unforgettable characters and a trip down memory lane with an army of characters past generations adored. How Disney managed to get the rights to all these familiar video game characters...it's not impossible that's for sure. Still, for a movie such as this breaking the whole fairy tale and old school Disney Classic ways, it was a major triumph. If you don't like video games you may not care for the humor, but Wreck-It Ralph still has the wonder and magic that all the Disney films before it have. To me this could very well be the best Disney (non-Pixar) film. Now, with this film apparently the first in a line of future original Disney film stories I am eager to see what's next. Also, as a Disney fan, it feels great wanting to go back to the theaters and see Disney Classics again, it has been a while.
summary: Disney found a new kind of magic!

Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Taking a page out of the "Toy Story" book, "Wreck It Ralph" is about the characters that populated our childhood, and what they do when we're not watching. (Unlike Woody and Buzz, however, these guys don't give a darn if the kids who play with them like them or not. It's just a job.) Ralph is the bad guy in a video game titled "Fix It Felix, Jr." that occupies space in an old-fashioned arcade - the kind that actually took quarters and was managed by a guy wearing, for some mysterious reason, a referee's striped shirt.When the arcade closes and the kids go home, the characters' lives go on. But Ralph doesn't have much of a life, because he's a bad guy, and everybody in his game hates him. The rest of the characters throw a party, but they don't invite Ralph. Instead, he goes to a Baddies Anonymous meeting, where he commiserates with Zangief (from "Street Fighter") and Bowser (from an endless number of "Mario" games) about how hard it is to be a bad guy. Zangief reminds him that "just because you are Bad Guy, doesn't mean you are bad...guy!" Their motto as a group is "I'm bad, and that's good." The meeting doesn't help Ralph much, maybe because he's not the one that needs to hear it. What they really have is a PR problem; instead of sitting in an Anonymous meeting, these bad guys really should be taking their message to the streets.Ralph decides he's going to win a medal, just like Felix does, and thus win the love and respect of the folks in his game. So he sneaks into a HALO-style first person shooter and steals the medal from the end, in the meanwhile setting off a chain of events that threaten the existence of the entire video game sub-world.This all happens in the first half hour, and, if this were just an average movie, I would be able to guess the rest of the film at this point in it. Ralph would spend the next 60(ish) minutes trying to clean up the mess he'd made, and in the process, he would save the video game world, and at the end, just when he thinks of himself as a bad guy for real, everyone would see him as a hero and they would give him the medal he so badly wanted and tried to steal.But this is a better, more interesting film than that. Ralph gets himself into trouble, and is plunged in to the candy-coated world of Sugar Rush, a go-kart racing game where nobody is quite what they seem. He loses his medal to a punk kid voiced by Sarah Silverman, and is forced into an agreement with her where if he helps her win a big race, she'll give him his medal back. But then King Candy, the ruler of Sugar Rush (voiced by Alan Tudyk, doing a spot-on and very entertaining impression of Ed Wynn from "Mary Poppins" and "Alice in Wonderland") pulls him aside to explain that if the kid is allowed to win the race, it would spell doom for the entire game, as well as certain death for her. What's Ralph to do?"Wreck It Ralph" does an excellent job of layering its exposition, so that a seemingly throwaway comment in one scene suddenly becomes an important plot point ten or twenty minutes later.  That's a pretty simple storytelling principle (though it's far too often ignored in Hollywood,) but what's really impressive is that these comments never feel like they're being dropped on purpose; it's never obvious that the screenwriters are telling us something we'll need to know later in the story.  That takes talent, and it's on display here.  "Wreck It Ralph" creates and inhabits a clearly unbelievable world, but it's written so well that it feels more believable, more lived in, than some movies that purport to exist in the real world.  Contrast this, for instance with "Looper;" that movie did a lot of things right, but the hints it dropped were so clunky and obvious that they broke the illusion; I knew what was coming well before it came, and spent nearly the last half of the film bored.Another of the things that I loved about this film was that both main characters' quest for actualization puts their respective worlds in jeopardy.  When Ralph is absent from "Fix It Felix, Jr." the game can't function, and the real world owner of the arcade (the guy in the referee shirt) prepares to junk it. The punk kid (I've been avoiding her name, because it's such an unholy mouthful, but for the record, it's Vanellope Von Schweetz) feels in her bones that she's a racer, but following that impulse threatens to bring her whole world down around her ears.  Their problems look like personal problems, but really, they're community problems; for both of them, the perspective of their entire community is going to need to shift before things can be restored to order and harmony.That's an awfully academic paragraph about a kids' movie.  But "Wreck It Ralph" isn't your run-of-the-mill kids' movie. It passed the kids' test in my house; my 4 year old likes it, though she thinks the bugs are too scary. I like it, too, because it offers something deeper, meatier and more nuanced for adult eyes.  And I'm not just talking about the '80s video game references that go right over my pre schooler's head.  This is one I won't mind watching over and over again.Random Notes:A lot of critics complained about the "Sugar Rush," segment of the film, saying that it was nauseatingly bright, aimed at drawing girls into the movie, and rife with product placement.  But go-cart racing games are ALWAYS like that.  Mario Kart exists in a cartoon world, that's part of what makes it so fun.  So does Diddy Kong Racing, and CTR, the two I played the most (and love the best) those college days I was supposed to be writing essays about Kierkegaard.  As a twenty something male, I would have played Sugar Rush.  I would have obsessed over it.If I have one complaint with "Wreck-It Ralph," it might be that the voice actors are a little TOO familiar, if that's possible.  Jack McBrayer makes Felix basically the same character as the one he plays on 30 Rock.  McBrayer's a funny guy, but it's disappointing he doesn't have more range.  Same with Jane Lynch; she's basically playing Sue Sylvester in an armored suit, right down to the weird verbal stylings ("Fear is a four letter word, ladies.  If you want to go pee pee in your big boy slacks, keep it to yourself" is totally something Sue would say.)I have to admit - the nostalgia kicked in.  I had to stop the film multiple times to Wikipedia video games I had forgotten about but had spent countless hours playing when I was a kid.One thing Ralph gets wrong: Asteroids and Centipede are two of very few games from 30 years ago that are still around.Would Skrillex really play "Celebration" by Kool & the Gang at a party?  Hard to believe.They seem to be intentionally messing with gender stereotypes in the gamers.  A little girl plays Hero's Duty, and it's two jerk boys who tell her they're going to spend all day playing Sugar Rush.One thing that's always bothered me about "Toy Story."  How in the world can Buzz not be aware he's a toy if he has to go rigid and plastic every time Andy walks in the room?  Does he just black out and not remember being played with?
summary: Better, Deeper, More Layered Than Your Average Kids' Movie

reviewText: Wreck-it Ralph is a very entertaining and enjoyable movie. It's definitely got tons of references for gamers, but in the end, it's a kids movie through and through.There's a lot of humorous comedy in this movie and a few touching moments with the girl character, but in the end... I was really disappointed with the emphasis on Candy land. I was hoping that this movie would take place within his own world or a different game that gamers would better relate to, but instead it was all in candy land. Placing it in this setting made me feel like I was watching a movie that was aimed specifically for kids, rather than say... Toy Story where both adults and children could get the joke.Also, Sarah Silverman as the girl (glitch) character is grating. It's not really the character itself that's annoying, but the voice, ugh... who thought that casting was a good idea? Overall, definitely a movie for kids, but not quite geared enough for adults and gamers.
summary: Would have preferred less Candy land

reviewText: Pros:This movie appeals to everyone,especially gamersIconic game characters were niceIts very funny at timesThe chemistry between wreck it Ralph and sarah s.'s character was greatFelix Jr shined as well as wreck it ralphGreat character developmentPacingThe villain was decentSomething that will hold a child's attentionSomething for the older gamers who remembers pac man on AtariSummary:I just really loved this movie and you can tell the people loved the source material to make this film, its something for everyone.
summary: I really loved it, Gamers this is your movie
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: It is sad that every movie I see reinforces people to be ignorant of human behavior and we pay the consequences.  The movie Wreck It Ralph does this with the behavioral repertoire of Ralph where he counters lines like, "You can't mess with the program Ralph" SO of course Ralph does the opposite of what he is told and all the sheople love it.  The puppets don't see that people behave exactly how they were trained when movies are not involved.  Plus, these sheople actually learn that if they behave differently then what they were told they were not just reinforced differently, they have free will.  URGH!!!!  People should learn the brain works through the contingencies of reinforcement and behavior can be reinforced that espouses propaganda OR behavior is conditioned to be the opposite of what we are told OR behavior is somewhere in between DEPENDING on the circumstances, real world variables NOT mentalism or made up illusions like free will.  If people are reinforced to behave differently then the propaganda they were fed then that is how they were programmed.  Anyone can also see "good" and "bad", (what is "good" for you can be "bad" for someone else and vice versa), are relative AND the consequences that occur on schedules of reinforcement are what determines behavior, but every human I encounter is reinforced to never understand the evidence. They think "good" and "bad" are absolutes (LOL).  Therefore, every movie I see is a Wreck It Ralph clone AND we pay the price with pathetic entertainment and pathetic behavior.  People will always ignore The Reluctant Alliance: Behaviorism And Humanism that teaches people to facilitate effective humanism and reinforce trash like Wreck It Ralph to always rule!  SO have fun being a slave that makes movies like Wreck it Ralph to maintain your illusions that you are so free (LOL)!

reviewText: A very fun and very creative movie for the family.  I thoroughly enjoyed the movie as I used to enjoy video games in my younger years.  I highly recommend this.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Pretty good movie. I do think the story gets convoluted once it gets to the Sugar Rush stage of the movie. Vaneloppe is overly annoying IMHO. I like this movie more for all of the video game nostalgia than I do for the story itself which is kind of sad!
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: This movie is perfect for children and adults alike. There is something for everyone!! My five year old daughter absolutely loved it along with me and her dad! Highly recommend.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Before the invention of home video consoles or the smartphone games that are now so ubiquitous, there was the "arcade generation", who controlled their pixels at the arcade via quarters.  "Wreck-It Ralph" taps into that "arcade nostalgia" by focusing on the "downtime" exploits of the arcade's heroes and villains.For a basic plot summary, "Wreck-It Ralph" follows a premise very similar to "Toy Story" in that when the arcade closes for the night, the characters behind the glass come to life.  In one particular game entitled "Fix-It Felix Jr.", the "bad guy" character named Wreck-It Ralph (voice of John C. Reily) is having a rough time due to the fact that he is an outcast in his own game.  One day, Ralph decides to game-jump (a move that can have devastating consequences on all parties involved) in a quest to prove that he isn't all bad.  Along the way, he meets up with a "glitch" named Vanellope (Sarah Silverman), who helps him to understand what being a "good guy" is truly all about.Story-wise, this is pretty stock Disney fare.  It is a feel-good message that, at times, can get a little predictable.  The voice-overs match the characters, the plot moves along nicely, and overall it is just a well-paced film.  It is full of enough sight gags and crazy antics to hook the kiddies in right away and keep their interest throughout.Of course, the new era of Disney animation needs more than that, so the "hook" of this film is the nostalgia that adults will feel towards the arcade atmosphere.  The film has cameos from many past games (Bowser, Q*bert, & the Street Fighter cast being the most obvious), as well as pays homage to the "beeps and boops" and sometimes jerky motions of those old classics.  For true fans of the history of gaming, there are enough "easter eggs" hidden in the background, so to speak, to pique your interest and/or make you chuckle.Overall, "Wreck-It Ralph" is a fine film filled with humor, heart, and (most importantly) video game nostalgia.  It isn't quite as perfectly polished as some other Disney fare (thus the one-star deduction), but it still was fun to watch for both old and young.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: I really like this movie because it is fun, clever, and visually appealing. It is also fun to see all the old school video game characters.
Title: Wreck It Ralph

reviewText: Wreck-It Ralph is one awesome movie!  I recommend anyone who liked it to pick up this set.  I don't even own a 3D TV yet, but one day I might, and when I do, I'll have the movie for it!  PICK THIS UP!
